generalInfo:
You would be hard-pushed to find a more exciting tour of Bolivia than this two-week adventure. A guided small group tour, it takes in everything from trekking in Amboró National Park (home to nearly 1,000 bird species as well as pumas and ocelots) to a 4WD expedition around the Uyuni salt flats, a night in an ecolodge overlooking Lake Titicaca, and a series of vibrant cities.


Yes it covers all the highlights of Bolivia, but this is no whistle-stop tour. You’re exploring at a pace that allows you to really immerse yourself in landscapes like nowhere else in the world, and colourful indigenous culture. Accompanied by an expert tour leader who will ensure everything runs smoothly, you’ll also meet up regularly with local guides, capable of providing insights and anecdotes that will leave you in no doubt: Bolivia is one of the most remarkable countries in South America.


The itinerary below explains the many unforgettable experiences waiting for you in Bolivia, but we’ll cover some that are of particular note...

• A trek through Amboró National Park, where the tropical jungle provides habitat for an incredible range of species including jaguars, pumas, tapirs and over 900 types of bird.
• Meeting a former miner in Potosi to learn about the Bolivian ‘Silver Rush’ and its tragic impact on millions of indigenous people and African slaves.
• A three-day expedition through the Uyuni salt flats, Turkini Lagoon and Eduardo Avaroa National Reserve, and some truly out-of-this-world scenery.
• An overnight stay at an ecolodge on the Isle del Sol on Lake Titicaca, the world’s highest navigable body of water.
• Guided tour around the ruins of Tiwanaku, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This pre-Columbian city was founded around 1500BC.
• Soak in the thermal pools of Polque against a spectacular backdrop of geysers and volcanoes.


A small group tour of Bolivia has numerous advantages. Among them, the sociable side – by the end of the second day you’ll be on first-name terms with your fellow travellers and guide. By the end of the week, firm friends. Secondly, with limited group sizes, you can stay in smaller, often locally owned accommodations and eat in independent restaurants, all of which can make significant financial differences to Bolivian communities that don’t see a huge amount of tourism.

dayInfo.description: Begin your adventure in the high-altitude city of La Paz, the well-connected start point of many Bolivian adventures. At 5pm-6pm, say?hola?to your tour leader and fellow travellers, when we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Your tour leader then ensures a big Bolivian welcome by arranging a group dinner. Want more time in La Paz? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Alternatively, you can join our Discover Peru adventure before this trip begins. Accommodation: Qantu Hotel (or similar)

Bid farewell to La Paz and fly to Uyuni, home of the iconic salt flats. Our journey takes us off the well-paved road, so we jump in 4x4s to transfer (five to six hours, including stops) to our hotel in the desert. En route, we visit the Train Cemetery, a fascinating (and slightly eerie) collection of rusty vintage locomotives strewn in a barren landscape. We also stop in San Cristóbal, once one of the largest silver-mining producers in the country, for a fascinating history lesson. Accommodation: Tayka Del Desierto (or similar)

Our hotel’s location means we’re well placed to explore Eduardo Avaroa National Reserve today, a vast landscape featuring some of Bolivia’s great natural wonders. Travelling by 4x4, our first stop is Laguna Colorada to see its rusty-red waters. Then, we marvel at active geysers, boiling mud lakes and steam pools, before heading to Polques Thermal Baths, where those willing to brave the cold air can enjoy a dip in the warm waters. After, we visit Laguna Verde (Green Lagoon) and Laguna Blanca (White Lagoon) – a scenic end to today’s explorations. Today’s driving time is approximately 12 hours. Accommodation: Tayka Del Desierto (or similar)

We’re back to exploring the incredible landscapes of Bolivia. Start at Laguna Turquiri this morning, an area known for its variety of flora and fauna, and particularly for its diverse bird species. After, we visit a trio of scenic lakes, Cañapa, Hedionda and Honda, before we travel through the otherworldly landscapes of the Valley of Rocks and Stone Tree. We arrive around 5pm at our hotel made from salt – it’s sure to be a highlight of the adventure for many. Today’s driving time is approximately 12 hours. Accommodation: Palacio de Sal (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

Today is the moment many will have been waiting for – our exploration of the largest salt flats on Earth. Jumping into 4x4s, we witness this incredible landscape up close, with the chance to see salt pyramids and, during the dry season, hexagonal salt tiles on the ground, which stretch as far as the eye can see. There are wonderful photo opportunities throughout the year, and we have time to create some fun pictures. In the middle of the salt flats, we come to Incahuasi Island, known for its giant cacti and unusual fossils. This small island is an amazing sight, and we can walk across it for 360-degree views from the top. After more photo opportunities, we watch the sun set, with the light casting shadows and reflections on the water. Today’s driving time is approximately five to six hours. Accommodation: Palacio de Sal (or similar) Upgrade to a suite today – speak to your sales representative for more details

Bid farewell to the salt flats as we transfer (four hours) to Potosí. It was here the Spanish colonial empire made their riches, forcing thousands of indigenous people to extract huge quantities of silver through slave labour. At the entrance to the Cerro Rico mine, we hear from a former miner about its world-changing legacy and tragic past. Our experience takes us to a mining market, where vendors sell dynamite and chemical products used in the extraction process. Then, we visit an ingenio, a factory in which minerals are extracted, separated and processed. Finally, we see an active mine to learn how the workers get in and out (though we’re not allowed in there ourselves!). After, embark on a walking orientation tour of the city itself, seeing the colonial structures funded by the 16th-century silver rush. Accommodation: Hotel Santa Teresa (or similar)

Leaving Potosí in the morning, we head to Sucre, the capital of Bolivia, to catch our flight to La Paz, which typically includes a connection in Santa Cruz or Cochabamba. The evening is free to celebrate the adventure – your tour leader can arrange a group dinner where you can relive your favourite moments together. Accommodation: Qantu Hotel (or similar)

Our Bolivia trip ends in La Paz after breakfast, and we begin our return journeys home. Alternatively, if you’d like to explore more, speak to your sales representative about extending your stay. Continue your South American adventure on Discover Peru, which you can join after this trip. Speak to your sales representative to book.

generalInfo:
Immeasurably rich in geography, ecology, nature, culture and history, Bolivia has something for everyone. This trip takes you to the Andes, Altiplano, several valleys and the amazing Uyuni Salt Flat. All of this combined with the experience to visit local people who still maintain ancient cultural traditions.

Close to the city of La Paz you can explore the Andes and several sacred peaks respected by living cultures, where you also will see condors and herds of llamas and alpacas, and visit villages such as the historic Isla del Sol surrounded by the beautiful and amazingly blue Lake Titicaca.

Visit two colonial cities included in the UNESCO heritage program: Sucre the official capital of Bolivia and Potosi the silver capital in colonial times.

Also, travel surreal nature visiting Uyuni, the world's largest salt flat and have a great opportunity of enjoying spectacular sunsets or sunrises. Optional night star gazing experience.

dayInfo.description: La Paz. This tour through out the Andes and Altiplano starts by a warm welcome to the city of La Paz with a transfer to your hotel. Our guide will give a quick briefing on this spectacular ten-day tour that features some of the most remarkable destinations in Bolivia and South America. Depending on the time of your arrival to La Paz, there are optional half-day tours not far from this capital city available for request.

La Paz – Copacabana – Isla Del Sol. At 0800 hours you will take a car ride towards Lake Titicaca, for about 3.5 hours along the Andes, arriving first to Copacabana, a touristic town located on the shores the lake. We will embark a touristic boat crossing the steel blue waters of Titicaca for a 1.5 hr until the southern part of the Isla del Sol, landing near the Pilkocaina archaeological site from where we begin our slow 1.5 hr hike, enjoying views and many aspects of life in the island, and later reach our hotel for an overnight stay. The afternoon will be free to explore some viewpoints and enjoy more cool vistas of the island and Lake Titicaca. (B, L, D)

Isla del Sol- Copacabana – La Paz. Today we can have the opportunity to enjoy, weather wise, a beautiful sunrise over the fantastic landscapes of Lake Titicaca and the sacred peaks of the beautiful Cordillera Real! After breakfast we hike through the village of Yumani, also known as the garden of the Inca and visit the spring of Eternal Youth, where the Inca performed baptisms. Then we head to the bay port to travel back to Copacabana and visit the Virgen Morena and her church. Lunch in Copacabana and later drive back to the city of La Paz, arriving by sunset. (B, L)

La Paz - Sucre. In the morning, we will check out of the hotel in La Paz, and then be transported to the El Alto International Airport for a flight to Sucre, the historical capital and the most beautiful city of Bolivia. Among its many attractions, besides a great pleasant subtropical weather most of the year, we will visit the Recoleta Convent and its small plaza that offers a compelling and great view of Sucre and its surroundings. In the same neighborhood we will visit one of the best cultural museums in South America, the Indigenous Art Museum ASUR that features part of the cultural heritage of the Quechua cultures that still inhabit the central south part of Bolivia. We will also visit the narrow nearby streets, near the museum, where more locals exhibit their traditional and contemporary textile works. (B)

Downtown Sucre (and half-day tours out Sucre). After breakfast, there will be more to visit and learn about Sucre and its colonial and republican past. We will visit the best of downtown Sucre, the vibrant and colorful Plaza 25 de Mayo, that contains several main attractions such as the Sucre Cathedral, the old National Congress, and the Casa de la Libertad *, where you will have a guided tour about Bolivian history, and learn when Simon Bolivar signed Bolivia’s Act of Independence in 1825, creating a free republic of Bolivia. Lunch. Later visit to the Convento Felipe de Nery which offers nice views walking the top roofs of the convent and have appreciation of the architecture that make Sucre also one of the nicest cities in the Andes and a renown world heritage site by UNESCO. The rest of the afternoon will be free for your leisure. Or you also may consider these next two options: Option 1. On this day we can have a half day hike in Chataquilla and then visit Maruagua, a typical town of this part of Bolivia, or Option 2. Visit to Tarabuco Market, only Sundays. (B) * Casa de La Libertad is close Mondays and on Sundays it is open from 09:00 to 12:00 noon. San Felipe de Neri is open from Monday to Saturday from 3:00 pm to 6:00 pm

Sucre - Potosi. We will take an approximately a three-hour morning trip to Potosi, once considered the largest and richest city in the Americas, founded during the 16th century. The trip will take us crossing warm Andean subtropical valleys towards the higher Puna grasslands and reach the dry Altiplano located over 4,010 m (13,000 ft) above sea level. Upon arrival in Potosi, we will discuss amazing facts about the city, its narrow streets and mix of baroque, gothic and indigenous architecture - Potosi is considered another proud world heritage site in Bolivia. A visit to the impressive gothic-style Royal Mint House* is a must, since it has 400 years of history preserved within the museum. Other attractions include San Francisco and other churches. (B) * The Royal Mint House is closed on Mondays and in Sundays only open from 0900 to 1200 hrs; therefore, -on Mondays- we visit Santa Teresa Convent instead, a place that also show lots of the colonial history in Bolivia and the Americas.

Potosí - Colchani. At 0900 hrs, visit to the Mercado Minero (the Miner’s Market) to buy gifts for the Pachamama (Mother Earth), El Tio (the Devil or mine’s guardian) and the miners. Gifts consist of coca leaves, tobacco, candy, and alcohol. At arrival to the mine entrance of Cerro Rico mountain, we are given a special outfit which includes a coat, rubber boots and a helmet. Before entering the mine, we must first give an ‘offering’ to Mother Earth and the Devil, as the local miners do. Having done our offering, we move further into the mine through the tunnels that take us to different levels. On our way we will see groups of miners still working inside tunnels. After lunch, we depart to the Uyuni Salt Flat, riding for about 4 hours, stopping at the town of Pulacayo and at other viewpoints that allow us to photograph the interesting and contrasting landscape of the high Andes or Altiplano. Upon arrival in Colchani-the gateway to Salar de Uyuni--we will check into one of the special hotels made of salt blocks! (B, D)

Uyuni Salt Flat (Dry season: June-early November). Enjoy an amazing sunrise before breakfast! Later, we will board smaller 4WD vehicles to travel on the Uyuni Salt Flat. If you are traveling in the dry season our first stop will be Isla Incahuasi, where we can enjoy an iconic and unique 360-degree landscape view of the endless salt flat. Lunch in the middle of the salt flat, and as soon finished we continue crossing this spectacular place, heading north to reach the hillsides of the Tunupa Volcano, a perfect setting to learn more about the fascinating nature, geology, and history of human occupation in this unique and remote part of Bolivia. Optional: After dinner you can have a star gazing experience watching deep the night sky of the Uyuni Salt Flat which is usually starry. If night is clear, we will see dark constellations as observed by ancient cultures that inhabited the region and learn about the Aymara beliefs. (B, L, D) OR DIFFERENTLY if you are coming during the Wet season: Dec-March, the Uyuni Salt Flat is usually flooded, and crossing is forbidden due to travel safety. We will do our best to take you to specific locations in the salt flat margins where you can enjoy impressive water reflections and picture sunset and sunrises that make this place one the best for nature, also walk some distance in shallow waters. At this time of the year Uyuni is also spectacular for nature photography as well as for gazing up the mysterious night sky.
Uyuni- La Paz. Transfer to Uyuni’s airport to fly out to the City of La Paz. Upon arrival transfer to the hotel and free afternoon
Transfer to El Alto Int Airport. Last day in Bolivia, after breakfast we will check out of the hotel, and we will be transfer to El Alto airport or to the bus station (B)

generalInfo:
Enjoy the fantastic views of Lauca and Sajama, both nature protected areas located in the Chile-Bolivia border, very accessible from La Paz. Enjoy beautiful landscapes of the high Andes with endless Puna grasslands, delicate bogs and wetlands used by llamas, alpacas. Also enjoy walking in front of the steel blue-colored Laguna Chungará surrounded by several inactive volcanoes such as the Payachata or Twin Volcanoes, the Sajama Volcano, and others. You will visit old villages and small colonial churches.

Continue your journey crossing Lake Titicaca towards the magic Isla del Sol, having the beautiful Cordillera Real in the background and featuring several sacred snow peaks venerated since by pre Incan times to present.

Finally, travel the surreal Uyuni Salt Flat and Eduardo Avaroa Andean Fauna Reserve to have more chances of incredible photography of sunsets and sunrises, unforgettable views of water reflections, colorful lagoons, high-Andes deserts, geysers, rocky landscapes and volcanoes that are home of three flamingo species, raptors, waterfowl, playful vizcachas, troops of wild vicunas and the Andean Fox.

This photographic tour is one of the most inspiring options for your visit to South America, a good complement for the Amazon rainforest or an extension to Peru.

Featured activities
- Photography
- Short hikes
- Wildlife sighting
- Birdwatching

dayInfo.description: La Paz. Welcome to the City of La Paz, seat of the Bolivian government, and unique for its urban blend that mix traditions, modernity and living cultures. Short briefing about this photography tour featuring, Lauca and Sajama National Parks, Lake Titicaca, Uyuni Salt Flats and Colorful Lagoons. Transfer to hotel.

La Paz - Lauca National Park - Putre. We will be picked up at 08:30 am from our hotel in La Paz. The route takes us to the Tambo Quemado highway. We make a short stop at the Chilean border to get our passport stamped and our vehicle approved. Slowly we ascend into Lauca National Park to Lago Chungará and the Parinacota wetlands, where we will have spectacular views and great chances of photography of the Payachatas (twin snow-covered volcanoes), herds of llamas, alpacas, vicunas, and other Altiplano wildlife. We will watch the sunset at Parinacota before leaving Lauca National Park to head to Putre, a small town, at 3,500 m (11480 ft). Here we will have dinner and accommodation. (L, D)

Putre - Lauca National Park - Sajama National Park. Early in the morning we will have breakfast before we drive back to Lauca National Park. Get ready for another day of full photography on the way. We will learn more about grasslands and bogs, where troops of wild vicunas are peacefully grazing very close to the highway. Once we are in Parinacota, more herds of alpacas, llamas and wetland birds may be observed. We briefly visit this village and its colonial church before taking the main highway to Lago Chungará. Here we will enjoy exquisite midmorning reflections on the water of the Payachatas and Sajama volcanoes, as well as other small snow peaks and take as many photographs as we want. Lunch and return to Bolivia, driving the unpaved road to Sajama National Park. We stay for the night at Tomarapi Lodge inside the Park. There we will enjoy a peaceful evening of storytelling. (B, L, D)

Sajama National Park - La Paz. On the final day we start with a breakfast and then we hike through the Queñua forest, one of the highest forest stands in the world. Here we can take photos of the surrounding scenery. Later we visit Sajama village and drive to their local hot springs, where we can soak and experience profound solitude, surrounded by the Bolivian and Chilean mountain peaks. On the way back to La Paz we will stop at some points of interest to take more photographs. After lunch we drive to La Paz. (B, L)

Day 5: Lake Titicaca - Copacabana - Isla del Sol. Our trip to Lake Titicaca will start with a pick-up at 0730. The ride is about 3.5 hours, and the route is very photographic: featuring the Andean rural landscape, distant snow peaks of the Cordillera Real and views of Lake Titicaca as the road contours the landscape. Once in the town of Copacabana, we will embark on a boat for a 1.5-hour ride to Isla del Sol's southern part. We land near the Pilkokaina Archaeological Site, and slowly we hike to our hotel as we take pictures of the rural landscape and striking landscape of Lake Titicaca. Overnight in Isla del Sol. (B, L, D)

Day 6: Isla del Sol - Copacabana - La Paz. Today we will get up early, to admire an amazing sunrise over Lake Titicaca. The next hike in the Isla del Sol will be unforgettable for the views of 360 degrees: locals farming plots growing quinoa, barley, potato or corn, the same way their ancestors did centuries ago. Isla del Sol offers one of the most magical and beautiful landscapes in Bolivia and South America, with deep blue skies and nice weather. Another boat ride will take you back to Copacabana and then the trip continues to La Paz. There are several places where we can stop and enjoy photographing the Andes. (B, L)

La Paz - Uyuni - Tahua. Transfer to the International Airport to fly to Uyuni. This flight takes about 45 minutes, and right after landing there is an immediate tour to the train cemetery to photograph old trains that show a bit of the Bolivian history. Later a 45 minute ground transfer take us to Colchani -- the entrance to the immense Uyuni Salt Flat, and the beginning of many opportunities for more photography. Here we will learn about interesting geological and natural features of the Salt Flat, including the Ojos de Sal (or salt eyes), where ice cold healing water bubbles through the salt. At the island, we will walk among huge cacti, and once we reach the top, we will have a 360-degree view of this Salt Flat. We will take our time taking photographs and enjoying the scenery. Later we will travel north to Tunupa Volcano, we will look for a good location to take photographs of an amazing sunset. It is said that the Uyuni Salt flats are a paradise for photography lovers. After dinner gazing up at a starry night sky. If the night is clear, we will observe constellations and learn about the Aymara beliefs. (D, L, D)

8: Tahua - Siloli Desert. At 04:30 am don´t miss the beautiful sunrise! Great opportunity for photography. After breakfast, the tour will cross another section of the Uyuni´s Salt Flat; this time we will be travelling south towards the Ollague Volcano, which is currently mildly active. On the way we will stops to photograph several lagoons, such as Cañapa, Hedionda, Chiarcota, Honda, and Ramaditas which offer views of 3 different flamingo species: the James, the Andean and the Chilean, as well as wild troops of Vicuna. Lunch will be enjoyed on the way to the Siloli Desert. (B, L, D)

Siloli Desert - Uyuni. Today we continue our trip with many opportunities for photography on the way. We start by crossing the Siloli Desert; here we will stop to photograph some natural monuments carved by the wind, such as the Arbol de Piedra (Stone Tree). Thereafter, more chances for unique photography when we arrive to Laguna Colorada, where we will visit the shooting geysers and hot mud boiling ponds of Sol de Mañana. We will stop at the natural hot springs, with safe bathing temperatures, so we are welcome to soak for a while. Later we drive to the Salvador Dali Rock Desert and to Laguna Verde at the base of Licancabur Volcano for more photography. This tour will end by returning back to Uyuni town to fly back to La Paz. Transfer to the hotel (B, L)

La Paz - Muela del Diablo - Palca. Free morning to walk around the hotel. At 12 moon we start traveling south of the city for about 40 minutes to enjoy lunch. After we drive to Muela del Diablo-- an imposing mountain with a unique rock formation and shape-to photograph this. We will then drive to the Palca Valley to photograph the most beautiful mountain in La Paz: Illimani. Transfer to hotel (B, L)
Back home. Transfer to airport.

tourName: Bolivia salt flats tour from La Paz
generalInfo: Embark on a captivating expedition through Uyuni’s mesmerising landscapes, including the enchanting Train Cemetery, dazzling salt flats, vibrant lagoons, and striking geologic formations. Witness spectacular wildlife like flamingos, relax in soothing thermal waters, and spend immersive nights in the singular salt hotel and a remote hostel. This journey promises a blend of natural wonders and cultural richness, offering an unforgettable experience.

dayInfo.description: La Paz - Uyuni, Bolivia: Overnight Journey to Salt Flat Wonders Evening Departure from La Paz Get ready for a journey that blends comfort with anticipation! Board your overnight bus in La Paz and settle into your seat as the city lights fade behind you. Travel in Comfort Enjoy reclining seats and cozy blankets as you drift off to the gentle rhythm of the road. Let the long miles melt away while you rest up for the adventures ahead. The bus is equipped for overnight travel, ensuring a restful journey. Awaken in Uyuni As dawn breaks, you’ll arrive in Uyuni, feeling refreshed and eager. Step off the bus and breathe in the crisp highland air—your gateway to the surreal, spectacular salt flats awaits!

Uyuni - Villa Candelaria, Bolivia: Mystical Salt Flats & Train Relics Awaken in Uyuni As dawn breaks, you’ll arrive in Uyuni, feeling refreshed and eager. Step off the bus and breathe in the crisp highland air—your gateway to the surreal, spectacular salt flats awaits! Train Cemetery Exploration Begin exploring the Cementerio de Trenes—an eerie yet fascinating graveyard of old, rusting steam locomotives that lie scattered against the vast, surreal backdrop of the Uyuni Salt Flat. Perfect for unique photographs! Salt Production Tour at Colchani Next, witness firsthand the salt extraction and production processes at Colchani Village. Learn about traditional techniques and the local importance of salt. Visit the Salt Artisan Workshop Marvel at the exquisite salt crafts handcrafted meticulously by local artisans, transforming ordinary salt into artistic and beautiful souvenirs. Salt Piles and "Ojos de Sal" Stand in awe amidst towering salt piles that stretch into the horizon, then discover the mysterious Ojos de Sal—small, bubbling pools of water surrounded by endless expanses of crystalline white salt. Isla Incahuasi Adventure Step onto Isla Incahuasi, a picturesque cactus-covered island rising dramatically from the salt plains. Wander among giant cacti, savor panoramic views, and soak in the island's surreal beauty. Hotel de Sal Experience As the sun dips below the horizon, arrive at your unique overnight destination: Hotel de Sal. Constructed entirely from salt bricks, this accommodation offers you the rare experience of sleeping amidst the very essence of the Uyuni Salt Flats. Settle into your cozy salt-built room, then join your fellow travelers for a relaxing dinner, sharing stories and anticipation for tomorrow's adventures.

Villa Candelaria - Polques, Bolivia: Flamingo Lagoons & Surreal Desert Landscapes Energizing Breakfast Fuel yourself for today’s adventures with a tasty breakfast at Hotel de Sal, discussing the day's itinerary with fellow travelers. Departure to Volcán Ollague Commence your day's journey by heading toward Volcán Ollague, a spectacular active volcano boasting panoramic vistas and unforgettable landscapes. Lagunas con Flamencos: Cañapa, Hedionda & Honda Continue onwards to the dazzling saltwater lagoons, each teeming with thousands of graceful flamingos. Admire their vivid plumage contrasting beautifully with the dramatic scenery, and relish the stunning reflections mirrored on calm lagoon waters. Exploration of the Siloli Desert Drive through the remote expanses of the Siloli Desert, set amidst the Andes Mountains. Step into a surreal world of isolated, wind-sculpted rock formations, endless horizons, and mysterious beauty — ideal for capturing timeless photographs. Lunch break – amidst nature Pause to recharge with a pleasant outdoor lunch surrounded by the rugged beauty of the desert environment, embracing a unique moment of tranquillity under open skies. El Árbol de Piedra (The Stone Tree) Witness one of Bolivia’s iconic landmarks, the impressive Árbol de Piedra—a natural rock formation shaped remarkably like a wind-eroded stone tree standing solitary against the desolate terrain. Laguna Colorada Experience End your exciting day at the spectacular Laguna Colorada (Red Lagoon). Embrace the striking contrast between its deep red waters, vast white mineral deposits, and the stunningly pink flamingos gracing its shores—truly a magical sight. Evening Arrival at Albergue Laguna Colorada Settle into your cozy accommodations at the Laguna Colorada Hostel. Share delicious dinner and unforgettable stories, relaxing after an exceptional day immersed in nature’s wonders.

Polques - Uyuni - La Paz, Bolivia: Geysers, Hot Springs & Dalí Landscapes Early Morning Departure Rise early, bundle up warmly, and begin your unforgettable third-day journey towards some of the region’s most fascinating geological attractions. Sunrise at Geysers "Geiseres del Sol de Mañana" Experience an otherworldly sunrise at the impressive geyser field "Sol de Mañana," a spectacular landscape of bubbling hot mud pools and columns of steam erupting powerfully from the earth. Take stunning photos amidst this surreal scenery. Morning Relaxation—Aguas Termales Reward yourself with a soothing dip in the natural thermal waters, the Aguas Termales. Relax, unwind, and rejuvenate as you soak in mineral-rich, comfortably heated pools while enjoying breathtaking surrounding views. Breakfast in Nature After your relaxing thermal experience, savor a nourishing open-air breakfast amidst magnificent scenery, preparing yourself for continued exploration. Surreal Rocas de Dalí (Dalí’s Rocks) Venture onwards to Rocas de Dalí, a fascinating rock formation landscape whose shapes and stark contrasts seem plucked straight from the imagination of legendary surrealist Salvador Dalí himself. Laguna Verde & Laguna Blanca Witness the mesmerizing natural beauty of Laguna Verde (Green Lagoon) and Laguna Blanca (White Lagoon). Marvel at their striking colors—ranging from emerald green to pearly white—as the stunning Licancabur Volcano provides a majestic backdrop perfect for photography. Valle de Rocas (Valley of Rocks) Continue your journey to Valle de Rocas, exploring extraordinary rock formations carved by the elements over countless millennia. Wander among towering rocky pillars and arches sculpted in fascinating shapes. Charming Villages—Culplina & San Cristóbal Finish your adventure passing through traditional Bolivian villages, Culplina and San Cristóbal, gaining a unique snapshot of high-Andean culture and village life amid spectacular regional vistas Return to Uyuni Arrive back to Uyuni, concluding your incredible three-day exploration, rich with memories, stunning photographs, and unforgettable experiences. Starlit Journey Across the Altiplano Night—As the bus makes its way through the sweeping high plains, enjoy a peaceful ride beneath glittering Andean stars, winding down from your adventure.

La Paz, Bolivia: Starlight Farewell: Uyuni to La Paz Arrival in Vibrant La Paz Early Morning— Wake up as the city of La Paz comes into view, famous for its dramatic mountains and bustling energy—the perfect place to end your trip or begin a new chapter.

tourName: Bolivia salt lakes, lagunas & volcanoes holiday
placesVisited: Uyuni, Salar de Uyuni salt flats, 4WD tour, Community-owned lodges, Volcano Thunupa, Laguna Colorada flamingos, Eduardo Avaroa Andean Fauna National Reserve, San Pedro de Quemes, Charagua, Polques hot springs, Volcano Licancabur
generalInfo:
Mind blowing vistas, multi-coloured lagunas, geysers, hot springs, flamingos and volcanoes greet travellers on this three-day small group tour across Bolivia’s high-altitude desert in search of one of the most remote and striking landscapes in South America; the Salar de Uyuni salt flats.

Using 4WD vehicles fully equipped with radios, GPS, oxygen and first aid kits, this trip is designed for the travellers who want more comfortable accommodation than is usually offered on this route.

Using a network of community-owned and very comfortable midrange hotels this trip offers guests an excellent opportunity to support local Aymara people in one of the poorest regions of Bolivia. Each property is sustainably built on land rented from local communities using local materials (including salt!) – and ownership will pass back to the communities after seven years. Accommodation is of a high standard, with private bathrooms, solar hot water and heating. And delicious buffet-style food is locally sourced where possible; Llama Bolognese anyone?

Starting and finishing in the small town of Uyuni, this is a small group tour with weekly departures, however longer itineraries including other activities and other areas of Bolivia, Chile or Peru can be tailor made if required. It is also possible to finish this tour at San Pedro de Atacama in Chile.

dayInfo.description: Today we have an unforgettable journey through 12,000 km ² of fantastic landscapes of salt. Prepare your camera - the dazzling white mantle of the Uyuni Salt Flat (or Thunhupha) resembles an immense glacier. In the winter (dry season, from May to October), when the surface hardens, geometrical formations start appearing formed by salt particles conglomerating into polygons. In summer (rainy season, November to February), the saline desert transforms into a gigantic mirror that melts into the purest sky in America. We come onto the salt flat through Colchani and its salt factories. We visit one of these and receive an explanation from one of the resident family about the economy of the salt industry which governs the life of the people here, and who have organised a co-operative organization. We then visit the salt plains - where the mounds of salt are collected. After the visit, we head towards Incahuasi Island. The tourist centre here has a path, which we climb, to the summit, from where we get a great 360 view. We'll have a box lunch at the island and then head toward the dominant Volcano Thunupa and the Chantani Museum. The museum features stone that resemble animals and mummies from the old burials in these lands. We arrive at Tayka Salt Hotel, settle in, and then head off by car to the town of Chillguilla at north, where we'll start the climb to Pucara. We walk for 20 minutes, climbing to the impressive site of Pucara Chillima. It is an quiet corner of the Salt Flat and a spiritual spot thanks to the stone buildings which are more than thousand years old. Return to Tayka Salt Hotel with private bathrooms, hot water and heating.

Today we focus on less visited parts of the Salt Flat. We head by 4x4 to Chiquini, making a stop in a lonely Ojo de Agua (Water Eye) then continue toward “The Cathedral”, a huge cliff facing the Salt Flat and very near the Chiquini Cave. Here there are strange geological underwater formations, from de time of Lake Michin (300,000 years ago) and Lake Mauca (40, 000 years ago). Next we cross from north to south, the most beautiful part in the white desert, far from the usual route of the tourists. We head towards the bay of the Campanas Islands, dominated by Volcano Caltama. We leave the salt flat and head to Charagua, a pretty place of corrals and goat farmers. It will take us one hour, via a bumpy road, to reach the Burnt Town of San Pedro de Quemes, where we will leave the car to wander in its small streets and view the buildings which inspired the hotel Tayka of Stone. We have lunch in the Hotel of Stone (optional Llama Shepherding trip, spending an hour or so helping a shepherd or shepherdess with the llamas, a vital part of life in the Salar). In the afternoon we will head for the lagoons - Cañapa, Hedionda, Chiarkota, Honda and Ramaditas, full of flamingos happy to be photographed! Other birds, such as Andean gulls and ducks, accompany the flamingos in these lagoons, which are flanked by snow-capped volcanoes. Next we enter the deserts of sand and the range of terracottas: red, oranges, ochers, coffees and beige - every bend in the road offers more colours. In front of the most impressive of these palettes of colours is the Hotel Tayka of the Desert, with private bathrooms, hot water and environmental heating.

An early start today at 05:30 o'clock, towards the Eduardo Avaroa and Flora and Andean Fauna Reserve and then the famous Stone Tree. Next is the Red Lagoon to observe its large population of flamingos, then to the Morning Sun Geysers to catch them in their most active moments. This will be the highest point in the route at nearly 5,000m. Here, noisy fumaroles and spluttering reddish mud puddles. The desert and salt flat of Chalviri is another superb scene. It combines the white of the snow, the ochre of the desert, the blue of the water, and, in one of its corners, the Hot Springs of Polques where you can take a dip. It is a day full of highlights, as next is Ladies of the Desert, a masterpiece created by the the wind and the Andean peaks around, with crazily shaped rocks in fantastic colours. Nearby is Green Lagoon, at the foot of the Volcano Licancabur, another pearl of the reserve. From the Green Lagoon we return to the Red Lagoon, have lunch, and then watch as the shifting sun helps to change its colour to blood red. We return via Villa Mar to Uyuni, and the tour ends.

tourName: Bolivia small group tour, Bolivia uncovered
generalInfo:
The neighbouring countries of Chile and Bolivia share some of Latin America’s most remarkable landscapes – this tour takes us from the montane forests of central Bolivia to the high altitude deserts of the altiplano. With South America’s largest percentage of indigenous people, unique species of wildlife that are still being discovered, and some of the continent’s best landscapes, Bolivia should be on every traveller’s list. We start our journey in Amboro National Park, one of the
most biodiverse areas on the planet, spanning varying ecosystems and elevations, and home to around sixty percent of the country’s bird species. Then we fly to Uyuni on the Southern Altiplano, our gateway to one of the most extreme and expansive vistas on earth, the Salar de Uyuni. As we travel through the high altitude plains we come across strange rock formations, boiling hot mud pools, and landscapes like a painter’s palette of colour, with brightly hued lakes and glistening salt flats stretching to the horizon.

The adventure continues as we cross into Chile. Exploring the Atacama Desert we visit steaming geysers, hot springs, lunar-like rock formations and turquoise lagoons. This is the driest region on harsh landscapes support a surprising amount of wildlife, which we’ll keep an eye out for.

This tour explores some of the wilder areas of the continent, where human presence is few and far between, and the raw elements of nature run riot. Every twist and turn - and there will be a fair few along the way – will leave you completely wonderstruck.

dayInfo.description: La Paz - Arrive into La Paz and transfer to hotel. Overnight Hotel Naira or similar.

El Alto – Head to El Alto to admire the futuristic buildings designed by famous Bolivian architect, Freddy Mamani. This evening we see a wrestling match, in which the ‘Fighting Cholitas’ wrestle to stand their ground, displaying female empowerment and fighting for gender and racial equality. Overnight Hotel Naira or similar. (B)

La Paz - Moon Valley - Today we explore the city, including the immense Cathedral, Presidential Palace and the 16th century San Francisco Church, then head to the intriguing, if rather gruesome, Witches’ Market to see the strange collection of good luck charms and ritual products on offer. In the afternoon we travel south of La Paz to see the rock structures and lunar landscapes of Moon Valley, and take a ride on the cable car for a bird’s eye view of La Paz and neighbouring El Alto. Overnight Hotel Naira or similar. (BL)

Santa Cruz – Amboro National Park Transfer to the airport and fly to Santa Cruz. On arrival we drive to Amboro National Park. The park is home to 1200 species of vertebrates, 840 of which are birds, making it one of the richest regions for wild birds in the world. The habitat here is also home for the Spectacled bear, jaguar, puma, and various species of monkeys and reptiles. In the afternoon we head out to explore the forest with fantastic views of the surrounding craggy cliffs. Overnight Refugio Volcanes or similar. (BLD)

Amboro National Park - Samaipata After breakfast we take a leisurely walk among the beautiful landscapes and stop for a dip in a natural pool fed by a waterfall. In the afternoon we set off for Samaipata, passing tropical forests, fruit plantations and small towns. Driving through a narrow valley we reach Samaipata, a small colonial town nestled amid gentle rolling hills. Overnight Pueblito Resort or similar. (BLD)

Samaipata - Santa Cruz - In the morning we visit the pre-Inca ruins of El Fuerte, once the site of an important administrative and religious centre. In the afternoon we visit the small Archaeological Museum of Samaipata, for a deeper understanding of these mysterious ruins. Return to Santa Cruz. Overnight Hotel Tryp or similar. (BL)
La Paz - Transfer to the airport in Santa Cruz and fly to La Paz. Overnight Hotel Naira or similar. (B)

Animas Valley – Palca Canyon - Head out of La Paz to Valle De Las Animas, where we take a hike (2h) and keep an eye out for wildlife such as chinchillas and the Andean Condor along the way. Heading back to the car, we drive down to Palca Canyon for lunch before continuing our hike (2h) through this breathtaking canyon with its monumental rock formations stretching up to 200m high. Return to La Paz for the night. Overnight Hotel Naira or similar. (BL)

Uyuni – Colchani – Salar de Uyuni – San Pedro de Quemes - Transfer to the airport and fly to Uyuni. The first stop of the day is the train cemetery in Colchani, where we will see the rusty remains of hollowed out train bodies that date back to the early 20th century. We visit a salt-processing town and then continue on to the other-worldly wonder that is the Salar de Uyuni. We also stop to admire the rare ecosystem of Incahuasi Island, an island covered with ancient cacti that can grow up to 18 metres tall, and the ‘chullpares’ which are old burial sites of ancient mummies. Overnight Takya de Sal or similar. (BLD)

Ojo de Perdiz - After breakfast we join a local family as they take their llamas to graze and we see a part of the salt flats that is largely ignored by tourists, despite its unrivalled beauty. Later we travel through the Chiguana salt flats to see the Ollague Volcano, with its fine columns of smoke – the only active volcano in Bolivia - and to the deserts of Ojo de Perdiz, via the Cañapa and Hedionda lagoons. The lagoons are towered over by snowy peaks and are populated by large colonies of flamingos and other birds such as ducks and Wallata geese. Overnight Takya del Desierto or similar. (BLD)

Siloli Desert – San Pedro de Atacama - Travel through the Siloli desert (4500m), where we might be lucky to see a viscacha or two. This high-altitude desert is scattered with rock outcrops that have been sandblasted into surreal shapes. We stop at the Stone Tree, shaped by erosion over thousands of years. Driving south, we visit Laguna Verde and Laguna Colorada (green and red lagoons). Their piercing colours make for some incredible photography, especially when the red lagoon is dotted with pink flamingos. We also stop at the Sol de Mañana geyser, before continuing to the border with Chile. In Chile, we head to San Pedro de Atacama. Overnight La Casa de Don Tomas or similar. (BL)

Atacama Salt Flats - Exploring the area surrounding San Pedro, we head first to the deep blue lakes of Miniques and Miscanti and from here we continue to the Salar de Atacama, the second largest salt flat on the planet after Bolivia’s Salar de Uyuni. We also make a stop at the red rocks named ‘Piedras Rojas de Hierro’. Overnight La Casa de Don Tomas or similar. (BL)

Tatio Geysers – Tebenquinche Lagoon - An early start takes us the Tatio geysers, the world’s highest geothermal field – early mornings are the best time to visit as the geysers send great plumes of steam into the air. From here we continue exploring the Salar de Atacama. We visit the Laguna Cejar, the salt content of which is higher than the Dead Sea, then the Tebenquinche lagoon, where flamingos come to feed. Overnight La Casa de Don Tomas or similar. (B)

San Pedro de Atacama - Just outside of San Pedro de Atacama, we visit a private reserve that is crossed by the Puritana River. The underground geothermal activity here means that the pools formed by the river have been transformed into hot springs. We spend some time relaxing in the springs, at 3500m above sea level and surrounded by the scenery of the high Andean puna. In the afternoon we visit the striking landscapes of Moon Valley. Overnight La Casa de Don Tomas or similar. (B)
Calama – Santiago - Transfer to Calama and fly to Chile’s cosmopolitan capital, Santiago, for the last night of your tour. Overnight MR Providencia or similar. (B)
Santiago - Transfer to the airport for your flight home.

tourName: Bolivia small group tour, Lowlands to The Andes
placesVisited: Santa Cruz de la Sierra, Chiquitania, Sucre, Dinosaur Footprints, Jatun Yampara, Potosi, Uyuni Salt Flats, Incawasi Island, Siloli Desert, Laguna Verde, Laguna Colorada, La Paz, Tiwanaku
generalInfo:
This Bolivia small group tour takes you from the lowlands to the Andes over two weeks, along with expert guides and likeminded fellow travellers. Bolivia is often bypassed in favour of its more famous neighbours, but it has everything you could want from an adventurous South American trip - and what’s more, you won’t have to share the experience with hordes of other tourists.

The variety of landscapes in Bolivia is stunning, and over the course of your journey, you’ll visit the barren expanses of the Uyuni Salt flats, the lush rainforests of the Amazon, the soaring mountains of the High Andes and the sweeping dunes of the Siloli Desert.

Culture is another important aspect of this tour and you’ll have the chance to interact with some of Bolivia’s many indigenous communities, learn about the days of the conquistadors while visiting the country’s fascinating colonial cities, and be transported back to ancient times with a visit to Tiwanaku – home to ruined temples and palaces dating from pre-Inca times

dayInfo.description: Santa Cruz de la Sierra - Arrive in the atmospheric city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra where you will be met and transferred to your hotel to relax after your flight. In the afternoon begin a city walking tour at the busy main square of 24 de Septiembre, including the main sights such as the church of San Lorenzo, the History Museum, and the handicrafts market of Recova Vieja. Overnight at Hotel Americana or similar. Depending on your time of arrival, the activities on this day may differ; if you arrive in the morning a visit to Guembe Biological Centre will be done.

Samaipata (approx. driving time 2.5 hours) - Today we visit the Fort and village of Samaipata. En route we have spectacular views of the Los Volcanes mountain range, and on arrival we take a 45-minute guided tour of the archaeological site. We discover the pre-Columbian architecture in the ruins of the defensive, religious and esoteric buildings. In addition, we hear the history of Fort Samaipata, which has belonged to the Chané, Inca and Spanish civilizations. After our stroll we visit the Samaipata Archaeological Museum, located just 12 miles from the archaeological complex. This colonial building exhibits the objects discovered during the excavations of the fort in its six rooms. After lunch at a local restaurant, we’ll start our return journey back to Santa Cruz de la Sierra, making stops along the way at Las Cuevas waterfalls where we take a hike of approx. 1 hour and a half round trip to visit the rain forest and bathe in pools. We return to Santa Cruz de la Sierra. Overnight at Hotel Las Americas or similar. (BL)

Sucre - This morning we transfer to the airport to catch the short flight south to “The White City” of Sucre (2.700m). After lunch we visit the impressive paleontological site of Cal Orck’o to see the rock face with its thousands of dinosaur tracks. On our way back to Sucre we visit the Indian market to understand the local folklore. After a short coffee break, we walk up to the roof of the tower of the San Felipe Neri Church. Overnight Hotel De Su Merced or similar (B).

Sucre – Potosi (approx. 3 hours driving) This morning begins with a visit to the Museum Casa de la Libertad, the site of the declaration of independence, for an insight into the history of Bolivia. We then drive to the Recoleta viewpoint for panoramic views across the city, and visit Museo Asur to learn something of the development of textiles in the region. We will continue on foot to enjoy close up, the wonderful colonial buildings and churches. After lunch we depart Sucre for Potosi City driving through beautiful landscapes. Overnight at Hotel Santa Teresa or similar (B)

Potosi - This morning we will travel by bus to visit the mines of Potosi. After donning appropriate clothing (helmet, torch etc.) we take a short ride to the Cerro Rico (Rich Mountain). Every day the miners celebrate the ritual of the Challa with offerings to Tio, the demon who is said to own the underground mineral riches. This afternoon we visit the Money Museum with its artefacts of a bygone age including machinery, utensils and coinage. Overnight at Hotel Santa Teresa or similar (B)

Potosi– Uyuni (205 kms, approx. 5 hours) - This morning we depart for Uyuni, stopping en route in the canyons of Porco, Andean wetlands and the Cacti Forest, and after lunch we travel by road to the town of Uyuni. Overnight at Hotel Casa de Sal, Magia de Uyuni or similar (B)

Salt Flat of Uyuni – Quemes (approx. 7 hours driving time) - This morning we take a short journey to visit the “graveyard of trains” a collection of historic steam locomotives and railcars, dating back several hundred years. We continue to the village of Colchani and witness how the locals transform the natural salt to edible salt using rustic ovens and tools. Colchani is the entrance to the fabulous salt flat of Uyuni, and we will take an impressive 3 hour cross country drive across the salt flat, with only track ways as points of reference. We stop en route at Incawasi Island to explore an area of giant volcanic ash rocks accompanied by hundreds of giant cactus rising up all around. Our journey across this remote area is undoubtedly one of the highlights of the trip. We finally move out of the salt flat towards the hamlet of Quemes. Overnight at Tayka Hotel de Piedra or similar (BLD)

Desierto Siloli (approx. 7 hours driving time) - Today we pass by the lava flows of Ollague, and a series of colourful lakes (Chiguana, Hedionda, Honda), which are home to great concentrations of Andean birds. On the approach to the Siloli Desert (Ojo de Perdíz) stand huge Aeolian formations of surreal figures, before the shrubby vegetation disappears completely, giving way to dunes. After a journey time of around 6 hours we arrive at a country hotel in the middle of the desert where we will sleep at 4600m. Overnight at Tayka Hotel del Desierto or similar (BLD)

Mallku - This morning we drive for around an hour and a half until we arrive at Laguna Colorada which is a burnt orange colour as a result of algae in the water. Generous mineral deposits line the shores and sustain a large concentration of flamingos. We continue to the extreme south west of Bolivia passing by the geysers of Sol de Mañana at 4950m, before arriving at the hot springs of Chalviri for a late breakfast, with some time for bathing. Return to Chalviri for lunch and 4 hours to travel to the Canyons of Mallku passing en route by the Valley of rocks and the Neolithic rupestrian paintings of Mallku. Overnight at Hotel Mallku Cueva or similar (BLD)

Uyuni (approx. 6 hours driving time) - Today we return to Uyuni following a more direct route but passing by the Canyons of Mallu, the Valley of Rocks and the Negra Lagoon and arriving by mid-afternoon where you will have some time at leisure. Overnight at Hotel Casa de Sal or similar (B)

La Paz and Tiwanaku - This morning we catch a flight to La Paz at 8.30am and transfer to the city and on arrival. we will take the 2 hour drive to the archaeological ruins of Tiwanaku to explore the temples and palaces originating from Pre-Inca times. We will return to La Paz in the late afternoon. Overnight at Hotel Bivouac or similar. (BL)

La Paz - Today will be spent discovering the sights of La Paz starting with main square Plaza Murillo and the streets around it where we can still find colonial architecture from the 16th century. We will visit the Museum of Magic Instruments and the Indian market. We will also take in the Witches Market known for the potions and magic amulets. We will drive to the cable car for a journey across the city from north to south, and drive to Moon Valley which is actually a maze of canyons and pinnacles formed by erosion. Overnight at Hotel Bivouac or similar (B)

La Paz – Copacabana & Lake Titicaca (Overall driving time is approx. 4 hours) - Today we head towards the Titicaca, stopping on the way to visit the museum of Paulino Esteban, the Bolivian Indian that built the boat RA II which crossed successfully the Atlantic Ocean. Enjoy the fascinating history and learn about how to do this kind of reed boats using the totora reed, endemic to the Andes. Later, at about midday we arrive in Copacabana (3825m / 12546 ft) on the shores of Lake Titicaca. This is a beautiful town and a popular resort and pilgrimage area, with lots to see and several nearby hills, which offer commanding views over the lake and towards the Cordillera Real. At the beach of Copacabana embark on a motor boat and continue the journey for another hour as far as the extreme southern side of the Sun Island (Isla del Sol) where we land near an Inca temple called Pilkokaina to have lunch in a typical restaurant with superb view over the lake to enjoy a traditional late lunch. Then, visit the Pilkokaina temple and walk about one hour to the Lodge Pallakasa. In the late afternoon, depart to walk up to the highest point of the island (4070 m/13350 ft) in time for a colourful sunset over the lake. Return to the lodge for the diner and overnight. Overnight Lodge Pallakasa or similar (BLD)

Copacabana – La Paz - In the morning walk approx. 1 hour to descend to an idyllic Garden with an Inca spring considered by the locals a fountain of youth. We then take a boat to the Moon Island (about 45 minutes driving). Visit the Temple of the Sun virgins Aclla Huasi where the girls were educated to be sacrificed. Walk for another hour to the hamlet Coati to catch our boat and travel to the replicas of floating islands of the Urus people to stop and catch some trout for our lunch. Finally return to Copacabana for a short visit to the Indian markets and the famous Church of Copacabana that shelters to the famous Virgin of La Candelaria before returning to La Paz. Overnight at Hotel Bivouac or similar (BL)
La Paz Departure - At your convenience we transfer to the airport for your onward flight. (B)

generalInfo:
Move over the northern Pantanal as we have a new contender for the best place in the world to see Jaguars and other (usually elusive) South American wildlife. The Bolivian wetlands and chaco forests are home to large numbers of jaguars, pumas, ocelots, tapirs, anteaters and many other species.

Introduction:
We have developed this unique cat specialist trip to Bolivia for anyone wanting to avoid the crowds in Brazil and enjoy spotting jaguars, pumas, ocelots and possible jaguarondis in the wonderful remote Bolivian pantanal. There is a huge range of wildlife found in Bolivia including endemic river dolphins, various armadillos, rare peccaries, endemic primates, as well as very rare and localised macaws and anacondas as well as many more on this unique Bolivian wildlife tour.

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife watching holidays that focus on one specific rare or elusive species of mammals. These trips are specialised in that they have a distinct focus, a species which is the overall target for the tour. But of course we are exploring the wonderful and diverse natural environment and many other species can also be seen. However this is the only specialist mammal tour focusing on the ecosystems of Bolivia.

This tour visits two particular areas for wildlife, including a private reserve in the Bolivian pantanal which is part of the same huge wetland ecosystem which spreads out into Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay. The private reserve offers the chance for some of the most spectacular wildlife watching in South America. The reserve encompasses the various ecosystems which make up the Pantanal, including grasslands, tropical forest, lakes and cattle ranching land all of which increases the density of divesity of life as well as making wildlife watching much easier than in thick forests and most other regions.

One of the major draw cards for Bolivia over Brazil is that very few people visit this region, in fact only a handful of guides are allowed to visit this private reserve and so on these trips we avoid the vast crowds of the Pantanal and we can observe wildlife in peace.

In the short time we have been running trips to this reserve we have an amazing 100% success rate for seeing Jaguars and we also have a very high success rate in seeing Ocelots, Lowland Tapirs, Pink Dolphins (endemic to Bolivia), Sloth, Anteaters, Marsh Deer and much more. But it is not just mammals which are spectacular here, the birding is phenomenal with over 270 species being recorded here. The larger more colourful species which can be found include various macaws, king vultures, spoonbills, toucans, sunbitterns and more.

The second place we visit on this trip is the internationally famous yet rarely visited Kaa Iya National Park in search of the elusive Jaguar, Tapir and Puma. We will explore this park in the morning, afternoon and during the night with spotlighting from our 4x4 vehicle.

This tour heads into the heart of the Bolivia Chaco which is a wonderfully diverse ecosystem. As well as safari drives and hikes we will be setting up and checking our camera traps to see what wildlife is around when we are not there to see.

All of this will be done with the expert guidance of local naturalist guides and where possible our own zoologist guides (where available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) also. All you have to do is to get in touch with your budget and your group size and where you would like to go and we will come back to you with an itinerary and quote for your perfect specialist Bolivian cat focused mammal watching tour.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner) where mentioned, in some locations lunch and dinner are not included (please refer to the itinerary), such as in Santa Cruz. There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers and safaris. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (when available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) who will escort you on all your excursions and we also have very knowledgeable English speaking local naturalist guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Bolivia. Your naturalist escort is an expert in wildlife biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge where we are going to visit. We have to camp in the remote areas we visit and all camping equipment will be provided with the exception of sleeping bags or sleeping liners. Where needed we further employ local guides at specific locations where their intimate knowledge of individual reserves and parks is invaluable in finding our targeted species. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, park entrance fees and permits. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the field. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour (subject to availability of a zoologist guide).

Seasons:

During September to October the weather in the Bolivian Pantanal and Chaco ecosystems is hot and dry (although it is the end of the dry season and the occassional early rain can occur). The temperatures during the day and night are hot and they heat up quickly in the morning. At this time of year the rainy season is approaching and whilst rain is rare at this time of year it is not unheard of for a tropical storm to blow in.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by an experienced naturalist as well as local drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife you’re watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• Our local naturalist guides have their ears to the ground and are constantly scouting new areas for rare and unusual wildlife. So we know of all of the locations to visit and we have the adaptability to change our plan (if needed) to take advantage of better wildlife watching in other locations whilst on the trip.
• We will stay in a variety of accommodation when on this tour, from hotels in Santa Cruz to camping and basic accommodation.
• Spend all the daylight hours searching for wildlife as well as spotlighting as many mammal species are nocturnal.
• All the above reasons give this, our specialist mammal watching tours give us a great success rate of seeing our targeted species (as well as many others). We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Bolivia so that we can try and find and observe mammals and many more species. We also have the ability to organise and run wildlife tours of Bolivia at other times of year and focusing on other groups of wildlife such as birds, reptiles & amphibians or even botany as well as other groups of animals or even specific species such as jaguars, maned wolves, giant armadillos etc. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour focused on 2 particular locations, firstly the vast wetland ecosystem of the Pantanal as part of the private reserve and then the drier more scrub forest ecosystem of the Bolivian Chaco.

Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from a vehicle (4x4) but we also include hiking where needed to have a better chance of seeing wildlife. There is no particular high level of fitness required and so the trip requires no special hiking experience or a specific level of physical fitness. This is a very easy trip to undertake.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 15 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Santa Cruz - Arrival On your arrival into Santa Cruz airport you will be met by your local guide/driver and take to your hotel for the night. The rest of the day will be free. Santa Cruz is one of the fastest growing cities on the world, it’s often ignored as a tourist destination in favour of its more touristic rivals like Sucre and La Paz. If you wish you can arrange a half day sightseeing tour of the city with your local guide at extra cost. (no meals included today).

Jaguar Land Reserve - Travelling & Wildlife Watching After breakfast this morning you will be transferred approximately 5 hours to a wonderful private reserve which is well known in the area for jaguar sightings. We will have lunch on the way at a local restaurant and reach the reserve in the mid afternoon. Along the way we have a good chance to see a lot of flora and fauna such as spectacled caimans, various species of macaws, three-toed sloths and a variety of monkey species primates. Once we arrive at the reserve we will continue to the camp site (we hope for some permanent housing in the near future, but at present this is a camping trip). The camp will be set up (complete with large comfortable tents, air mattresses and all other camping equipment needed) and we will unpack and then we will explore the reserve for the first time. We will explore the reserve in our own private 4×4 vehicle. We will be looking for a wealth of wildlife, including the highlight; Jaguars. We will return to the camp for dinner and then head out after dark for spotlighting, looking for ocelots and other nocturnal species. (all meals included)

Jaguar Land Reserve - Wildlife Watching Today is a full day exploring the reserve, with an early start and vehicle safari again looking for Jaguars, Marsh deer, Macaws, Pink Dolphins and many more species. We will return to the camp for breakfast and then later lunch. Then after lunch we will head back out into the reserve for our second safari of the day. Once again after dinner at the camp you will have a second night drive looking for Puma, Jaguar, Ocelots, Tapirs and more nocturnal species. (all meals included today)

Jaguar Land Reserve / Santa Cruz - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning will be your last morning in the reserve looking for wildlife. After your final drive you will have breakfast as the camp is packed up, before leaving back for Santa Cruz. We will have lunch en route before getting back to the city hotel in the late afternoon. (breakfast and lunch included today)

Kaa Iya National Park - Travelling & Wildlife Watching Once again you will be collected from the hotel after breakfast and we will depart for our next destination. The drive to Kaa Iya National Park is a full day and we will stop after 260km (~3.5 hours) at the town of San Jose. Here we have lunch at one of the local restaurants. We then drive a further 90km off road to enter the park, please note, Pumas, Peccaries, Toucans, Jaguars and more have been seen on this drive so have the cameras ready. Once inside the park, we sign in with the Park rangers and set up bedding and equipment before the late afternoon safari. We will then set out for a trek along the pipeline in search of Jaguars and more, Big cat and tapir tracks and scat are extremely common and an excellent indication of how many large mammals live in the park. After dinner we will do a night spotlighting drive or a night walk. (all meals included today).

Kaa Iya National Park / Santa Cruz - Wildlife Watching & Travelling Today will be your last chance to see wildlife in Kaa Iya National Park, you will have one final safari drive as we leave the park. We will stop for lunch in San Jose de Chiquitos before we return to Santa Cruz in the evening. The rest of the day is at your leisure. (breakfast and lunch are included today)

Trinidad (Mamore & Ibare Rivers) - Travelling & Wildlife Watching This morning we will go to the airport in Santa Cruz and fly to Trinidad. Arriving around 10am we will then be collected transfered to port on the Mamore / Ibare Rivers where we will have a full day private boat trip looking for the endemic Bolivian pink dolphins, three-toed Sloths and much more wildlife in the river and along the forested banks. We will have dinner in a nearby boutique hotel. (breakfast and lunch are the only meals included today).

Gran Mojas - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning will be an early start as we head to the Gran Mojas searching for the critically endangered and endemic to Bolivia, Blue-throated macaw. This species is only found in a few remote areas on the planet and today we have a good chance of seeing them. Also around here is the Beniano anaconda which is another rare Bolivian endemic species and of course much more wildlife too. We will have dinner in the boutique hotel (breakfast is the only meal included today).

Santa Cruz - Travelling & Day of Rest This morning you will be transferred to the airport after breakfast to catch the flight back to Santa Cruz, where you will be met and taken to the hotel. The rest of the day is free to explore the city or just rest before the flight back home. (no meals are included today).
Home After breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (breakfast only included)

generalInfo:
Bolivia is a destination yet to be discovered by many travellers, yet its spectacular landscapes and thriving folkloric culture present even the most world-weary adventurers with something new. In a continent racing to reach modernity, Bolivia surely offers the most authentic Latin American experience.

From isolated Andean peaks to the steamy headwaters of the Amazon, Bolivia humbly delivers breath-taking landscapes and outstanding natural beauty, all far from the tread of the well-worn tourist path.

Among a crumbling colonial legacy, Bolivia is striving to secure a more prosperous future while holding on the clothing, music, religions and even languages that are firmly rooted in its indigenous communities, whose ancestors pre-date the Spanish conquistadors.

Its land-locked isolation has helped preserve much of Bolivia’s ancient beliefs and traditions that give visitors a vibrant sense of how a world long-forgotten elsewhere can exist side-by-side with the modern urban landscape of business suits and wireless internet connections.

- Private transport with trusted drivers

- Unique, hand-picked accommodation
- Good quality meals, no 'tourist' restaurants
- Dedicated UK-based team member for assistance
- Safety assurance
- Flexibility: itinerary can be modified to your requirements

dayInfo.description: You will be picked up from the airport and transferred to your hotel. Santa Cruz city tour. Free afternoon to rest, walk through the hotel gardens or use of the hotel's swimming pools or facilities.

Fly to Sucre. Visit the Casa de la Libertad, where Bolivia's independence was signed, followed by the churches of San Lazaro and San Felipe Neri. Spend the afternoon at the indigenous art museum (ASUR) which showcases the best of traditional Bolivian textiles, and is situated in the Recoleta neighbourhood, offering lovely views of this pretty, colonial city.
Visit the Tarabuco village, located around 60km from Sucre (approximately 90 min journey), to see the indigenous community and its traditional Sunday market
Travel to Potosí which is situated at 4050 m.a.s.l. This colonial city sits at the foot of “Sumaj Orko”, once considered the richest mountain in America.

Travel from Potosi to Uyuni (approximately 3-hour journey). Today is the start of a 3-day journey into one of the world’s most isolated areas where you will be surrounded by a glittering white landscape. As soon as you arrive in Uyuni, you will have a brief stop in a small settlement called Colchani where the local people bring the salt that they have dug from the salt flat, they weigh it and bag it for sale at an artisanal scale.

The journey continues towards the Siloli desert and Coloured Lagoon. On route you will observe Volcano Ollague, Bolivia's only active volcano, as well as various coloured lakes, where 3 different types of Flamingos can be spotted. You will arrive at the Desert Hotel where you will stay the night

You will have an early start to visit the Morning Sun geysers at 5,000m above sea level. You will then head to the the dramatic Green Lagoon at the foot of Volcano Lincacabur, salt plains of Chalviri, the Valley of the Ladies of the Desert, and may also stop at some high altitude lagoons. You will travel back to the Uyuni Salt Flats.

Fly to La Paz. On the city tour of La Paz, at over 3,600 m.a.s.l. you will visit some of the city’s most important highlights: the San Francisco Church, the 'Witches’ Market', and the museums in the vicinity. You will then head to the 'Plaza Murillo', where the Legislative and Government Palaces are, and onto a replica of the semi-subterranean 'Temple of Tiwanaku'.

You depart for Coroico after breakfast and the drives takes approximately 2.5 hours from La Paz city centre. On route you travel through 'La Cumbre' and here you start a spectacular descent of more than 3,000m from a snow-capped mountain pass to near-tropical jungle in just 40 miles (64km). You stop at a turning where the road once dubbed 'the most dangerous on the planet' by the Inter-American Development Bank was until a few years ago, the only route from La Paz into the semi-tropical Yungas region. Today the road is mainly used by mountain bikers cycling downhill towards Coroico, and you have some time for photos and to take in the views, before your driver continues down the new and more modern road to Coroico.

Leave the city of La Paz for Tiwanaku, close to Desaguadero on the border with Peru. A 90 minute drive will take you to the archaeological site of Tiwanaku, one of Latin America’s most famous historical sites. In the afternoon you will transfer to Copacabana to enjoy the intense blue waters and the quaint Aymara villages along the way. You will cross the Straits of Tiquina by boat and continue by road to El Santuario de la Virgen Morena de Copacabana, you will visit the church, have a chance to admire local traditions and handicrafts before having lunch on the shores of the lake. In the afternoon you will visit the archaeological site known as the Horca del Inca, an Inca observatory.

Copacabana – Sun Island (Lake Titicaca): Today you have a full day excursion by boat to explore Bolivia’s hilly islands of solid rock amid Lake Titicaca. These islands are home to a few small communities of Aymara and Quechua speaking people who cultivate the islands, graze sheep and make handicrafts. They have no motorised transport on the islands. The navigation over to the Sun island takes approx 90 minutes, you disembark at Yumani dock from where there’s an unavoidable climb of 200 stairs taking you past Incan agricultural terraces which follow the contours of the island and the Inca’s terraced garden to the “Fuente de la Eterna Juventud” a natural spring that is said to be the source of eternal youth. Upon your return to Copacabana in the late afternoon you can visit the town’s beautiful cathedral, usually shining in the altitude’s bright sunlight.
Copacabana-La Paz: Morning transfer to La Paz (approximately 4 hour journey). Afternoon at leisure
Early this morning you are picked up from your hotel and transferred to La Paz's international airport for your flight to Santa Cruz
