dayInfo.description: Arrival La Paz. City Tour + Valle de la Luna (afternoon) Tour. Visit to the city, observing: the residential neighborhoods, the district of Miraflores, the replica of the Semi-subterraneous Temple of Tiwanaku, the Killi Killi viewpoint, the Plaza Murillo (Government Palace, Congress and the Cathedral), the Jaen street, the Gold Museum, the cable railway, the area of the Black Markets and the Witches Market. Hostal Naira all nights La Paz.

Tour Tiwanaku. Pick up from your hotel for a tour of approximately 05 hours to visit the ruins of Tiwanaku. On the way visit the Apacheta of Lloqo Lloqo from which we'll see another side of the Bolivian highlands, arriving at the ruins after 01 hour and a half. Visit to the Museum of Tiwanaku. Then we start the tour of the archaeological site to see the sacred religious precints, stone carved monoliths and the famous Puerta del Sol. Return to La Paz.

Condoriri mountains full day. We pick you up from your hotel, for a journey of about two and half hours to reach Tuni lagoon. From "Campo de Llamas" will begin a three-hour walk up to Chiarkhota lagoon (5379 m) base camp of the Condoriri massif. After lunch we will begin a walk around to observe the different peaks, such as Aguja Negra (5290 m.), Ilusión (5330 m.), Piramide Blanca (5230 m), Pequeño Alpamayo (5330 m) and others. Being surrounded the base camp (in a sort of horseshoe) by snowy mountains, is a privileged site for observing and photographing. At 15:00 approximately, we have a two hours walk to Tuni lagoon, before returning to La Paz.

Full day in the mountains. Pick up at hotel. Chacaltaya to Huayna Potosí Base Camp. Walk for 06 hours. On the way to Chacaltaya, we will make some stops to observe the city and its surroundings. Arriving at the lodge will begin a walk through the three mountain peaks, to observe the Cordillera Real, Lake Titicaca, the high-plateau and the snow-covered Huayna Potosi. Then we restart the walk along the edge of the mountain toward the Huayna Potosi. After some hours of walking it begins the descent down the valley of Milluni. There we take the car to visit the dam at the Zongo Pass and the base camp of Huayna Potosi. Return to La Paz.

Flight La Paz – Uyuni. Day 01: Salar de Uyuni group tour - 3 days, 3 nights. Visiting: the handicrafts in Colchani, the piles of salt, the salt museum, the great Uyuni salt field and Incahuasi Island which is located in the heart of the Salar and is characterized by the presence giant cactus. Lunch (Box-Lunch) on the Island. After lunch we will have free time to enjoy the scenery. We continue the journey to the town of San Juan.

Day 02: Salar de Uyuni group tour. After breakfast, depart from San Juan to Huayllajara. En route we will visit: the Mirador Ollague, the lagoons (Cañapa, Hedionda, Chiarkhota, Honda and Ramaditas), the Siloli desert, the Stone Tree and the Laguna Colorada. Lunch (box lunch) en route. Then continue towards Huayllajara, located 15 minutes from Laguna Colorada.

Day 03: Salar de Uyuni group tour. Departure from Huayllajara to Uyuni. En route we will visit: the geysers, the fumaroles, the hot springs of Polques. Breakfast en route. We continue to the Dali Desert and Laguna Verde. Returning to Uyuni, we will visit en route: the Valley of the Rocks, the authentic villages of Alota, Kulpina K and San Cristobal. Box Lunch on route. Arrival to Uyuni. Flight Uyuni – La Paz. Hostal Naira La Paz.

Mountain Bike Coroico Group Tour along spectacular Death road from Altiplano to mountain cloudforest. Can also be private guided or as private excursion by car. We can also replace this program with a day to Sajama National Park or a hiking day on glaciers. The Sajama volcano is located at the north of the volcanic chain. We are going to visit the Keñua forests and the hot springs of Kasilla. After lunch, we continue visiting the geysers, and then return to La Paz.
Departure La Paz and flight home, fly to Rio de Janeiro / Paraty beaches or continuation with another Latin American destination.

generalInfo:
Visit the world famous Salar de Uyuni Salt Lake, explore ancient ruins and float across Lake Titicaca in this unique adventure.

A wonderful adventure that will take you deep into the heart of Bolivia, a land steeped in history, culture, and unreal landscapes.

Begin in Santa Cruz, a city that blends modernity with tradition. Marvel at the Basilica Menor de San Lorenzo, an architectural gem that showcases the nation's religious heritage and ventures deeper into Bolivia's past as you visit the enigmatic Samaipata Ruins outside Santa Cruz. This ancient site bears witness to the prowess of pre-Incan cultures, with intricate stone carvings and ruins that seem to speak of bygone eras.

Next visit Sucre, a UNESCO World Heritage site and journey to Potosi famous for its silver wear before heading to the Salar de Uyuni, a true trip highlight. The Salar de Uyuni salt flat is an otherworldly expanse that stretches beyond the horizon. Here, pentagonal salt formations create a surreal landscape that meets endless blue skies, inviting you to really contemplate the wonders of nature. Stay in a salt hotel where everything from the floors to the ceilings to the furniture is made from local salt, an incredible experience and South America's answer to an ice hotel!

A short flight takes you to La Paz, the highest city in the world where you can travel around by cable car and visit the intriguing Witches' market. From one record-breaking height to another, head to Lake Titicaca, the highest navigable lake in the world. Discover the secrets of Sun Island, where ancient ruins and a sun temple, bear testament to the spiritual significance of this region. Relax in the tranquillity of the serene waters and the majesty of the Andes mountains that surround you.

dayInfo.description: SANTA CRUZ - On arrival in Santa Cruz take a brief transfer to Cortez Hotel, your accommodation for the next two nights. In the afternoon, head on a tour of Santa Cruz. Visit the Basilica Menor de San Lorenzo and immerse yourself in the local culture at Arte Campo, a well-known craft store. Explore the vibrant Abasto Indigenous Market and take in the city's iconic landmarks and charming residential areas. Afterwards, return to your hotel to unwind and relax for the remainder of the day.

SAMAIPATA RUINS - Start your day with breakfast before setting off on a full-day excursion to the Samaipata Ruins. Located approximately 120km from Santa Cruz, these ruins unveil the mysteries of a pre-Incan civilization, which constructed the archaeological site "El Fuerte" for rituals. Immerse yourself in history as you wander through the ruins and visit the archaeological museum showcasing precious artifacts unearthed at El Fuerte and its environs. Enjoy a lovely lunch during your journey. Upon returning to Santa Cruz, take the evening to explore the city or unwind at the hotel.

SANTA CRUZ -SUCRE - Following breakfast, it's time to catch your local flight to Sucre. Upon landing, you'll be taken to Hostal De Su Merced, your accommodation for the night. Next, enjoy a city tour of Sucre, exploring notable landmarks like The Recoleta and the House of Liberty, where Simon Bolivar solidified Bolivia's independence. Be amazed by the diverse array of goods at the local markets and perhaps find some souvenirs to take home!

SUCRE - POTOSI - UYUNI Today, your destination is Potosi, a UNESCO World Heritage city renowned for its silver riches. Prepare to be awestruck by the Casa de la Moneda (Royal Mint) and delve into its historical significance in producing silver coins during the colonial period. Enjoy lunch at a local restaurant before continuing your journey to Uyuni. Upon arrival, you'll be transferred to Hotel Luna Salada, nestled on the shores of the Uyuni Salt Lake, where you'll spend two nights. This extraordinary hotel is entirely crafted from locally sourced salt, from its walls to its furnishings and floors, offering a truly unparalleled experience.

SALAR DE UYUNI - Start your day with a delightful breakfast before heading on a morning adventure to the Uyuni Salt Lake. Check out the crystalline salt formations, towering cacti, and the expansive salt flats that together create a truly surreal landscape. Your journey continues with a visit to Isla "Incawasi," where you'll encounter unique formations of algae and fossils, surrounded by ancient cacti. Following a picturesque lunch, head to the village of Tahua nestled at the foot of Thunupa Volcano. Explore the cave housing the world's oldest known mummies, the Coquesa Mummies, before returning to your hotel for a tranquil rest.

UYUNI - LA PAZ Following breakfast, you'll be taken to the airport for your local flight to La Paz. Upon arrival, you'll be transferred to Hotel Casa Grande, your accommodation for the night. Embark on a half-day city tour to uncover the diverse charm of La Paz, encompassing its indigenous, colonial, and modern districts. Highlights include visits to the Indian Market, Witch Doctor's Market, and breathtaking vistas of the Illimani mountain. Explore the Moon Valley, experience a scenic ride on the Teleferico (cable car) overlooking the city, and then return to your hotel to relax and unwind.

LA PAZ - LAKE TITICACA Today marks the beginning of an unforgettable adventure from La Paz to Copacabana, over the enchanting waters of Lake Titicaca. Board a hydrofoil and glide across the lake to Sun Island, where you'll explore the Pilcocaina Sun Temple and head on a llama trek to your hotel. Following a delicious lunch, take advantage of the leisurely afternoon to discover the surrounding area. Enjoy dinner and a tranquil overnight stay at the "Posada del Inca" Eco Lodge.

LAKE TITICACA - Indulge in a leisurely breakfast and a tranquil morning at your pace. Around noon, descend the Inca "Grand Stairs" and try the water from the Sacred Fountain before enjoying lunch at Uma Kollu archaeological Restaurant. Following this, embark on a cruise to Moon Island, where you'll explore the Sun Virgins Temple "Iñak Uyu" before continuing your journey to Copacabana. There, immerse yourself in the rich culture as you visit its shrine and pay homage to the Indian Dark Virgin. Next, venture to Huatajata for a one-of-a-kind evening experience at "The Mystic World of the Kallawayas." Witness ancient healing rituals and engage with Tata Benjo, a revered Kallawaya, as he shares his profound knowledge. As night falls, prepare for a visit to the Native Observatory Alajpacha, where you'll gain insights into the Aymaran Cosmovision and the southern constellations. Conclude your day with dinner and a restful overnight stay at Hotel Inca Utama.

LAKE TITICACA - LA PAZ After breakfast head on an adventure to the Andean Roots Eco Village. Here, you'll have the opportunity to explore the Altiplano Museum and the Mud Igloos. Engage with the Limachi family, renowned for their craftsmanship in building legendary ocean-crossing vessels. Get up close and personal with adorable vicuñas, llamas, alpacas, and the graceful Suri. Following a delicious lunch, continue your journey to the Ruins of Tiwanaku, where you'll delve into the ancient culture's grandeur, architecture, and social organization. As the day draws to a close, return to La Paz for your final overnight stay at Hotel Casa Grande, reflecting on the rich experiences and memories gathered throughout your Andean adventure.
DEPART LA PAZ - After breakfast transfer to the airport for your onward flight for a safe journey home.

tourName: Bolivia wildlife holiday, jaguars and wild cats
generalInfo:
Move over the northern Pantanal as we have a new contender for the best place in the world to see Jaguars and other (usually elusive) South American wildlife. The Bolivian wetlands and chaco forests are home to large numbers of jaguars, pumas, ocelots, tapirs, anteaters and many other species.

Introduction:
We have developed this unique cat specialist trip to Bolivia for anyone wanting to avoid the crowds in Brazil and enjoy spotting jaguars, pumas, ocelots and possible jaguarondis in the wonderful remote Bolivian pantanal. There is a huge range of wildlife found in Bolivia including endemic river dolphins, various armadillos, rare peccaries, endemic primates, as well as very rare and localised macaws and anacondas as well as many more on this unique Bolivian wildlife tour.

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife watching holidays that focus on one specific rare or elusive species of mammals. These trips are specialised in that they have a distinct focus, a species which is the overall target for the tour. But of course we are exploring the wonderful and diverse natural environment and many other species can also be seen. However this is the only specialist mammal tour focusing on the ecosystems of Bolivia.

This tour visits two particular areas for wildlife, including a private reserve in the Bolivian pantanal which is part of the same huge wetland ecosystem which spreads out into Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay. The private reserve offers the chance for some of the most spectacular wildlife watching in South America. The reserve encompasses the various ecosystems which make up the Pantanal, including grasslands, tropical forest, lakes and cattle ranching land all of which increases the density of divesity of life as well as making wildlife watching much easier than in thick forests and most other regions.

One of the major draw cards for Bolivia over Brazil is that very few people visit this region, in fact only a handful of guides are allowed to visit this private reserve and so on these trips we avoid the vast crowds of the Pantanal and we can observe wildlife in peace.

In the short time we have been running trips to this reserve we have an amazing 100% success rate for seeing Jaguars and we also have a very high success rate in seeing Ocelots, Lowland Tapirs, Pink Dolphins (endemic to Bolivia), Sloth, Anteaters, Marsh Deer and much more. But it is not just mammals which are spectacular here, the birding is phenomenal with over 270 species being recorded here. The larger more colourful species which can be found include various macaws, king vultures, spoonbills, toucans, sunbitterns and more.

The second place we visit on this trip is the internationally famous yet rarely visited Kaa Iya National Park in search of the elusive Jaguar, Tapir and Puma. We will explore this park in the morning, afternoon and during the night with spotlighting from our 4x4 vehicle.

This tour heads into the heart of the Bolivia Chaco which is a wonderfully diverse ecosystem. As well as safari drives and hikes we will be setting up and checking our camera traps to see what wildlife is around when we are not there to see.

All of this will be done with the expert guidance of local naturalist guides and where possible our own zoologist guides (zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) and wildlife researchers also. All you have to do is to get in touch with your budget and your group size and where you would like to go and we will come back to you with an itinerary and quote for your perfect specialist Bolivian cat focused mammal watching tour.

Group Departure: 4-16 October 2023

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner) where mentioned, in some locations lunch and dinner are not included (please refer to the itinerary), such as in Santa Cruz. There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles with an excellent driver for all transfers and safaris. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (when available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) who will escort you on all your excursions and we also have very knowledgeable English speaking local naturalist guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Bolivia. Your naturalist escort is an expert in wildlife biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge where we are going to visit. We have to camp in the remote areas we visit and all camping equipment will be provided with the exception of sleeping bags or sleeping liners. Where needed we further employ local guides at specific locations where their intimate knowledge of individual reserves and parks is invaluable in finding our targeted species. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, park entrance fees and permits. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the field. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour (subject to availability of a zoologist guide - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us).

Seasons:

During September to October the weather in the Bolivian Pantanal and Chaco ecosystems is hot and dry (although it is the end of the dry season and the occassional early rain can occur). The temperatures during the day and night are hot and they heat up quickly in the morning. At this time of year the rainy season is approaching and whilst rain is rare at this time of year it is not unheard of for a tropical storm to blow in.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by an experienced naturalist as well as local drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife you’re watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• Our local naturalist guides have their ears to the ground and are constantly scouting new areas for rare and unusual wildlife. So we know of all of the locations to visit and we have the adaptability to change our plan (if needed) to take advantage of better wildlife watching in other locations whilst on the trip.
• We will stay in a variety of accommodation when on this tour, from hotels in Santa Cruz to camping and basic accommodation.
• Spend all the daylight hours searching for wildlife as well as spotlighting as many mammal species are nocturnal.
• All the above reasons give this, our specialist mammal watching tours give us a great success rate of seeing our targeted species (as well as many others). We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Bolivia so that we can try and find and observe mammals and many more species. We also have the ability to organise and run wildlife tours of Bolivia at other times of year and focusing on other groups of wildlife such as birds, reptiles & amphibians or even botany as well as other groups of animals or even specific species such as jaguars, maned wolves, giant armadillos etc. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour focused on 2 particular locations, firstly the vast wetland ecosystem of the Pantanal as part of the private reserve and then the drier more scrub forest ecosystem of the Bolivian Chaco.

Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from a vehicle (4x4) but we also include hiking where needed to have a better chance of seeing wildlife. There is no particular high level of fitness required and so the trip requires no special hiking experience or a specific level of physical fitness. This is a very easy trip to undertake.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 15 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Santa Cruz - Arrival On your arrival into Santa Cruz airport you will be met by your local guide/driver and take to your hotel for the night. The rest of the day will be free. Santa Cruz is one of the fastest growing cities on the world, it’s often ignored as a tourist destination in favour of its more touristic rivals like Sucre and La Paz. If you wish you can arrange a half day sightseeing tour of the city with your local guide at extra cost. (no meals included today).

Jaguar Land Reserve - Travelling & Wildlife Watching After breakfast this morning you will be transferred approximately 5 hours to a wonderful private reserve which is well known in the area for jaguar sightings. We will have lunch on the way at a local restaurant and reach the reserve in the mid afternoon. Along the way we have a good chance to see a lot of flora and fauna such as spectacled caimans, various species of macaws, three-toed sloths and a variety of monkey species primates. Once we arrive at the reserve we will continue to the camp site (we hope for some permanent housing in the near future, but at present this is a camping trip). The camp will be set up (complete with large comfortable tents, air mattresses and all other camping equipment needed) and we will unpack and then we will explore the reserve for the first time. We will explore the reserve in our own private 4×4 vehicle. We will be looking for a wealth of wildlife, including the highlight; Jaguars. We will return to the camp for dinner and then head out after dark for spotlighting, looking for ocelots and other nocturnal species. (all meals included)

Jaguar Land Reserve / Santa Cruz - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning will be your last morning in the reserve looking for wildlife. After your final drive you will have breakfast as the camp is packed up, before leaving back for Santa Cruz. We will have lunch en route before getting back to the city hotel in the late afternoon. (breakfast and lunch included today)

Kaa Iya National Park - Travelling & Wildlife Watching Once again you will be collected from the hotel after breakfast and we will depart for our next destination. The drive to Kaa Iya National Park is a full day and we will stop after 260km (~3.5 hours) at the town of San Jose. Here we have lunch at one of the local restaurants. We then drive a further 90km off road to enter the park, please note, Pumas, Peccaries, Toucans, Jaguars and more have been seen on this drive so have the cameras ready. Once inside the park, we sign in with the Park rangers and set up bedding and equipment before the late afternoon safari. We will then set out for a trek along the pipeline in search of Jaguars and more, Big cat and tapir tracks and scat are extremely common and an excellent indication of how many large mammals live in the park. After dinner we will do a night spotlighting drive or a night walk. (all meals included today).

Kaa Iya National Park / Santa Cruz - Wildlife Watching & Travelling Today will be your last chance to see wildlife in Kaa Iya National Park, you will have one final safari drive as we leave the park. We will stop for lunch in San Jose de Chiquitos before we return to Santa Cruz in the evening. The rest of the day is at your leisure. (breakfast and lunch are included today)

Trinidad (Mamore & Ibare Rivers) - Travelling & Wildlife Watching This morning we will go to the airport in Santa Cruz and fly to Trinidad. Arriving around 10am we will then be collected transfered to port on the Mamore / Ibare Rivers where we will have a full day private boat trip looking for the endemic Bolivian pink dolphins, three-toed Sloths and much more wildlife in the river and along the forested banks. We will have dinner in a nearby boutique hotel. (breakfast and lunch are the only meals included today).

Gran Mojas - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning will be an early start as we head to the Gran Mojas searching for the critically endangered and endemic to Bolivia, Blue-throated macaw. This species is only found in a few remote areas on the planet and today we have a good chance of seeing them. Also around here is the Beniano anaconda which is another rare Bolivian endemic species and of course much more wildlife too. We will have dinner in the boutique hotel (breakfast is the only meal included today).

Santa Cruz - Travelling & Day of Rest This morning you will be transferred to the airport after breakfast to catch the flight back to Santa Cruz, where you will be met and taken to the hotel. The rest of the day is free to explore the city or just rest before the flight back home. (no meals are included today).
Home After breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (breakfast only included)

placesVisited: Santiago, Valparaiso and the Casablanca Valley, Moon Valley and stargazing, Rainbow Valley, El Tatio Geysers, Altiplano Lagoons, Eduardo Avaroa National Park, Salar de Uyuni, the largest salt flat in the world, Tahua, La Paz, Lake Titicaca
generalInfo:
This epic adventure explores the Central Valley and Atacama Desert in Chile before crossing into Bolivia for the magical Salar de Uyuni, the dramatic setting of La Paz and the highest navigable lake in the world, Lake Titicaca.

Begin your journey in Santiago, Chile's lively hub, exploring historic landmarks and ascending San Cristobal Hill for panoramic vistas. Head to the coast to discover the hillside charm of Valparaiso and indulge in a range of wines in the Casablanca Valley.

From Santiago, the trip unfolds into the enchanting desert oasis of San Pedro de Atacama, a charming town surrounded by surreal landscapes. Traverse Moon Valley, meander through the altiplano adorned with mesmerising lagoons and absorb the culture of Socaire village. Rise early to witness the ethereal sunrise at El Tatio geysers amidst the barren altiplano.

Crossing into Bolivia, the adventure continues into Eduardo Avaroa National Park. Marvel at the emerald splendour of Laguna Verde, witness the geothermal marvels of "Sol de Mañana" Geysers, and be captivated by the vibrant red hues of Laguna Colorada. Days are filled with remarkable wildlife encounters, including flamingos, llamas, and vicuñas. Continue the Bolivian escapade in La Paz with a city tour and Teleferico cable car journey through the city with dramatic views of Mt Illimani.

Wrap up this incredible journey at Lake Titicaca with a hydrofoil cruise to Isla del Sol (Sun Island) where Indigenous traditions and stunning landscapes intertwine. This extraordinary adventure promises awe-inspiring landscapes, cultural richness, and unforgettable moments.

dayInfo.description: ARRIVAL IN SANTIAGO - Upon arrival at Santiago Airport, a warm welcome awaits, for your transfer to Le Reve Hotel in the heart of the city. Immerse yourself in Santiago's essence with a half-day tour, visiting iconic landmarks like Plaza de Armas, the Cathedral, Ahumada Boulevard, and "La Moneda" Government Palace. Explore Bellavista's charm, ascend San Cristobal Hill via a scenic bus ride for panoramic views, descend by cable-car and discover modern Santiago.

VALPARAISO & CASABLANCA VALLEY - On your full-day adventure, journey through the picturesque Casablanca Valley, renowned for its vineyards, on your way to the charming coastal town of Valparaiso, a UNESCO World Heritage site with unique hillside architecture. Explore narrow streets, climb charming stairways, and ride a funicular for panoramic views. Immerse yourself in the vibrant colours of the city's houses. Return to Santiago, pausing for a delicious lunch and a wine-tasting experience at the Casas del Bosque vineyard.

SANTIAGO to ATACAMA DESERT - Transfer to the airport for your short flight to Calama in the far north of Chile. Upon arrival you'll be transferred to the picturesque village of San Pedro de Atacama with breathtaking views of the Domekyo and Salt Mountain Ranges. In the afternoon, enjoy a shared excursion to the remarkable Moon Valley. This extraordinary desert landscape boasts unique geological formations shaped by wind and water. Explore the Amphitheatre, Salt Cave, and Tres Marías formations, capturing the essence of this awe-inspiring scenery. Conclude the day with a tranquil overnight stay at Hotel Kimal in the heart of San Pedro de Atacama.

ATACAMA DESERT - Join a full-day shared excursion to the high altiplano region, where the captivating blend of unique flora, fauna, and scenic lagoons awaits. Visit the spectacular Laguna Miscanti, the area's largest lagoon. Next, immerse yourself in the indigenous culture with a visit to the Socaire village, gaining insights into their traditional Atacameñan way of life. A simple yet satisfying lunch awaits at a local restaurant before you return to the comforts of Kimal Hotel in San Pedro de Atacama, concluding a day filled with natural wonders and cultural experiences.

ATACAMA DESERT - Depart San Pedro de Atacama early for a sunrise expedition to the altiplano. On your way to the stunning El Tatio geyser field, traverse varied altitude ecosystems, including the remarkable wetlands of Machuca and Putana. Behold the natural spectacle of steamy geysers against the backdrop of the rising sun. As the day begins, venture into the captivating "Geyser Blanco," where you can bask in thermal waters while you enjoy your breakfast. Return to San Pedro de Atacama, and the remainder of the day is yours to leisurely explore, reflecting on the wonders of the morning's high-altitude adventure.

ATACAMA DESERT - Spend the morning exploring the village of San Pedro de Atacama, its quaint church, and the local craft market. Later in the day, dive into the cultural and geological significance of Rainbow Valley and Yerbas Buenas sites. Discover the indigenous community in Rio Grande, followed by an exploration of Rainbow Valley's multi-coloured rock layers, revealing millions of years of history. Conclude the day by marvelling at the salt mountain range's unique geology and the distant beauty of the Andes before returning to your hotel.

CROSS TO BOLIVIA - Set off early to cross the border into Bolivia and the start of an unforgettable journey. The first stop is the mesmerising Eduardo Avaroa National Park, a vast wilderness thriving with unique flora and fauna adapted to extreme conditions. Discover the awe-inspiring Laguna Verde, a colossal emerald lake overseen by the towering Licancabur Volcano. Explore the "Sol de Mañana" Geysers, where volcanic craters and fumaroles spout steam and water up to 100 metres high and traverse the surreal landscape to reach Laguna Colorada, a red-hued lake inhabited by diverse wildlife, including flamingos. Conclude the day at Hotel Luna Salada, a hotel built entirely of salt on the edge of the sprawling Salar de Uyuni.

SALAR DE UYUNI - Visit the Salar de Uyuni, Earth's largest salt flat, spanning 12,000 square kilometres. Witness the surreal beauty of crystalline pentagons, vast skies, and towering cacti, crafting a dreamlike landscape. Explore "Incawasi," an oasis adorned with unique algae and ancient fossils, surrounded by colossal columnar cacti. Savour a picnic lunch amidst this otherworldly scenery. In the afternoon, retreat to your hotel for dinner and a tranquil night, cherishing the memories of a day immersed in the breathtaking expanse of the salt flats.

TAHUA & THUNUPA VOLCANO - After breakfast embark on a full-day excursion to Tahua, a picturesque village nestled at the base of Thunupa Volcano. Explore the village's charm and hike to the Coquesa Mummies Cave, housing the world's oldest known mummies. A delightful picnic lunch is provided, offering time to relish the serene beauty of the surroundings.

UYUNI to LA PAZ - Transfer to Uyuni Airport for short domestic flight to La Paz. Upon arrival, transfer to the Zona Sur area of the city and the modern, comfortable Casa Grande hotel. In the afternoon unravel the magic of La Paz. Visit the Indian Market, Witches' Market, and admire panoramic views of the majestic "Mt Illimani," the guardian of La Paz. Explore the Valle de la Luna, a natural wonder resembling the lunar surface. The trip concludes with an exhilarating Teleférico cable car ride, offering a spectacular aerial view of the city.

LAKE TITICACA - Depart La Paz for the small town Huatajata, a charming lakeside town nestled along the shores of Lake Titicaca. Explore the Andean Roots Eco Village, delving into the Altiplano Museum, Handicrafts Village, Mud Igloos, and the mortuary towers of the Urus Chipayas. Encounter the Limachi family, renowned builders of the legendary expedition reed boat vessels RA II and Tigris. Continue by hydrofoil cruise to Sun Island, ascending the Inca "Grand Stairs," and savouring the sacred water from the Fountain of Eternal Youth. Lunch beckons at the Uma Kollu archaeological Restaurant, followed by a visit to a quaint Indian market. Extend your journey to Moon Island and the Sun Virgins Temple "Iñak Uyu" before returning to Copacabana and return to La Paz. As you traverse the altiplano, admire the majestic Cordillera Real backdrop.
DEPART LA PAZ - Transfer to the airport for your onward flight concluding your remarkable Bolivian adventure, replete with natural wonders, cultural revelations, and indelible memories.

dayInfo.description: Medellín: Hola and a warm welcome to Medellín, Colombia! Your South America adventure officially begins this morning in the hotel lounge, where you'll meet your fellow travellers and your Adventure Leader for a quick trip briefing. This will cover travel plans, important safety tips for the region, and everything you need to know to make the most of your time here. Once the details are covered, we’ll dive straight into your first unmissable experience – a guided walk through Comuna 13. This vibrant neighbourhood is famous for its captivating street art, rich culture, and remarkable history of transformation. Once a hotbed of conflict, it’s now a symbol of resilience and urban renewal, with highlights like outdoor escalators offering stunning city views and beautiful murals that celebrate hope and progress. After soaking in the sights, we'll head to the Mercado del Río for a group lunch. This local food market is bursting with Colombian delicacies, and it's the perfect place to fuel up for the day ahead. Next, it’s time to brush up on your Spanish! Your Adventure Leader will lead you through a brief Spanish class, teaching some useful phrases that will come in handy throughout your tour. Once you're ready, we’ll set off for a stroll around Medellín’s most iconic landmarks, including Plaza Botero, the Palacio de la Cultura Rafael Uribe Uribe, and the Catedral Basílica Metropolitana. For culture lovers, this is a must! If you’re after a bit of adventure, why not take to the skies with a paragliding flight to get a bird’s-eye view of the city below? When the evening rolls around, the fun doesn’t stop! We’ve got a couple of optional activities lined up: - If the football gods are on our side, we’ll take you to Estadio Atanasio Giradot for a local soccer game. The atmosphere here is electric! - If there’s no game, you can try your hand at Tejo, a unique Colombian game where you throw clay discs at gunpowder-filled targets to make a small explosion. Trust us, it’s a blast! - Not in the mood for sports? No worries! Head over to El Poblado, Medellín’s lively party district, where you can kick back with a drink and enjoy some salsa dancing to end the night on a high note. It’s the perfect start to what’s sure to be an incredible journey!

Medellín: Start your second day the Colombian way with a steaming cup of locally produced coffee – and let us tell you, Medellín is home to some of the best! It’s the perfect way to fuel up for a day of adventure. Next, we’re off for a day trip to Guatapé, a colourful lakeside town known for its vibrant zócalos (decorative murals), charming cobblestone streets, and lively atmosphere. This place is a true feast for the eyes! We’ll kick things off with a bit of a challenge – the 740 steps to the top of El Peñón de Guatapé, a massive granite rock that offers awe-inspiring panoramic views of the surrounding lakes and lush landscapes. Don’t worry, the view at the top will make every step worth it! After we’ve conquered the rock, take some time to explore the town of Guatapé. Wander through its charming streets, and immerse yourself in its vibrant colours and unique culture. Then, it’s time for a more tranquil adventure – kayaking on the Peñol-Guatapé Reservoir. We’ll pair up in kayaks (2 per kayak) and paddle through the serene waters, taking in the stunning scenery of the surrounding rolling hills, colourful houses, and, of course, the majestic rock we just climbed. It’s the perfect way to appreciate the beauty of the area from a different perspective. In the evening, we’re diving into another quintessential Colombian experience – tango! Thanks to the influence of the legendary Carlos Gardel, tango is a part of Medellín’s cultural fabric. Join your group for a lively tango dancing class where you’ll learn the sultry rhythms and energetic moves that make this dance a cultural icon. It’s a fun, passionate way to end the day!

Salento: This morning, we’re up and out early, heading to our next destination – Salento! Nestled in the heart of the Coffee Triangle, this charming town is known for its vibrant colonial architecture, lush coffee plantations, and stunning views of the Cocora Valley’s iconic towering wax palms. We’ll be transferring by minivan (roughly 6-7 hours), arriving in Salento in the early afternoon where your Adventure Leader will greet you. Coffee lovers, get ready for an unforgettable experience! This afternoon, we’ll explore the Finca el Ocaso Coffee Farm. From hand-picking the beans to learning about the coffee-making process firsthand, you’ll dive deep into the world of Colombian coffee. Of course, there will be a tasting session so you can savor the final product – by the end, you’ll be a true coffee connoisseur! Afterwards, the rest of the day is yours to enjoy at your leisure. Why not take a stroll through Salento’s picturesque central plaza, soaking in the atmosphere and local culture? You could also explore the town’s quirky shops, enjoy a traditional meal, or just unwind and take in the views.

Cali: Today, we’re off to our next destination in Colombia – the vibrant city of Cali, famous for its lively salsa scene and stunning mountain surroundings! We’ll transfer by bus, arriving in Cali late in the morning, where your Adventure Leader will greet you. After checking in, you can take some time to relax by the pool at your hostel and recharge after the journey. In the late afternoon, we’ll set out to explore some of the city’s highlights, starting with the Plaza de Caycedo, Cali’s central square. Here, you’ll find towering palm trees, a bustling atmosphere, and a historical significance as the heart of the city. We’ll also visit the beautiful Catedral Metropolitana, an impressive Neo-Gothic cathedral that overlooks the plaza, renowned for its architectural beauty and cultural importance. With a local guide, we’ll delve into the rebellious spirit of Cali – wandering its lively streets to discover the cultural roots of salsa, its impact on social movements, and its artistic expression through vibrant murals and music. The evening is yours to enjoy however you like. For those feeling adventurous, why not dance the night away at one of Cali’s most popular salsa clubs? You’ve got a relaxing morning ahead, so don’t be shy – let the rhythm of salsa take over!

Cali to Bogotá: As promised, enjoy a peaceful morning soaking up the sun and unwinding by the pool – the perfect way to recharge after the excitement of Cali. In the afternoon, we’ll head to the airport for a short flight to Bogotá, Colombia's vibrant capital city nestled high in the Andes. Upon arrival, we’ll transfer to your hostel, where you can take the evening to relax and prepare for the adventures that await in this dynamic city!

Bogotá: What better way to start our day than with a bike tour to get a feel for Bogotá’s diverse neighborhoods? We’ll pedal through the vibrant streets of La Candelaria, exploring the historic downtown, including Plaza Bolívar, the impressive Cathedral, and the Presidential Palace. Next, we’ll stop by a traditional fruit market where you can sample exotic Colombian fruits like lulo, uchuva, passion fruit, and more, while making our way through local neighborhoods. After that, we’ll cycle through a middle-class district, offering a glimpse of modern Colombian life and some of Bogotá’s lovely national parks. Later, we’ll dive into the city’s thriving street art scene with a graffiti tour! You’ll learn about Colombia’s history, culture, and politics as we admire the vibrant murals and art pieces. You’ll even get the chance to try your hand at spray painting your own creation! As the sun begins to set, it’s time for some epic views. We’ll take the funicular up to Monserrate, a mountain standing over 3,000 meters above sea level, offering stunning panoramic views of the entire city. Be sure to explore the area, including the church and the surrounding sights, before heading back down via cable car. The evening is yours to enjoy as you wish. If you're up for it, why not check out Theatron – the biggest nightclub in Latin America?

Bogotá to Cusco: After a week of exploration, it's time to journey into a new country on your South American adventure – Peru! This morning, we’ll head to the airport for a direct flight to Cusco, the former capital of the Incan Empire and the gateway to the famous Sacred Valley and Machu Picchu. On arrival in the afternoon, we’ll kick off our adventure with a guided walk through Cusco’s charming historic downtown. We’ll visit iconic landmarks like the Plaza de Armas, the impressive Cusco Cathedral, and the bustling San Pedro Market, where you can immerse yourself in the local culture. We’ll wrap up the day with a delicious group meal, where you’ll get to sample some of Peru’s traditional dishes – think hearty stews, succulent meats, and fresh local produce! Just a heads-up: You’ll need lots of energy for the next three action-packed days, so an early night might be a good idea to recharge for the adventure ahead!

Inca Trail: Today marks the start of one of the most unforgettable experiences of your tour – a 4-day trek to Machu Picchu! Get ready to immerse yourself in the breathtaking beauty of the Andes. And don’t worry, your food is all taken care of – after all, there are no shops in the mountains! Today’s hike will be a relatively easy one, designed to help you acclimatise to the altitude while soaking in the stunning Andean vistas. You’ll only need to carry a light day pack, as your larger luggage will be transported separately. As the day comes to a close, we’ll set up camp and enjoy a delicious dinner prepared by our expert trekking team. Then, take a moment to look up and marvel at the vast Milky Way, lighting up the clear night sky above the Andes. This is a moment you won’t forget! Our 4-day, 3-night trek to Machu Picchu follows the iconic Inca Trail, one of the most legendary and scenic routes in the world. However, permits for the Inca Trail are extremely limited and tend to sell out 4-6 months in advance. While our first priority will always be to secure these permits for you, if we’re unable to get them, we’ll arrange permits for the Salkantay Trek as an excellent alternative. The Salkantay Trek takes a different route but offers just as much stunning scenery, following a path through the Andes mountains, and lasting the same length of time. Whether you’re on the Inca Trail or the Salkantay Trek, you’re in for an unforgettable adventure on your way to the magnificent Machu Picchu!

Inca Trail: Day two of our trek kicks off with an early start, as we embark on a more challenging stretch of the journey. Today, we’ll traverse mountain passes, explore small archaeological sites, and immerse ourselves in the breathtaking natural beauty of the Andes. Keep your eyes peeled for hummingbirds flitting through the air – these colorful little creatures are a common sight in this region, adding an extra dash of wonder to your trek. Expect a more intense pace today, with some steep climbs that’ll test your stamina. The final stretch will see us hiking uphill for a couple of hours to reach our next campsite, where a warm meal and stunning views will await you. After this challenging day, relax and enjoy the tranquil atmosphere of the campsite under the stars. You've earned it!

Inca Trail: Day three of our hike is undoubtedly one of the most awe-inspiring, with jaw-dropping views and unforgettable Inca history along the way. We’ll begin the day with a gentle climb that leads to spectacular panoramas of the surrounding landscapes, giving you a well-earned chance to appreciate the beauty of the Andes. As we continue, we’ll reach Phuyupatamarca, one of the most significant Inca archaeological sites, perched at the third-highest point along the trail. From here, we’ll begin our descent toward the next leg of our journey. The climate shifts as we move from the cooler altitudes of the high Andes to the warmer, more humid air of the Amazon jungle. On the way down, we’ll pass Intipata, an incredible agricultural site with terraced fields, offering a glimpse into the ingenuity of the ancient Incas. After today’s hike, we’ll arrive at our third campsite in the afternoon. With plenty of time to relax, you can take in the views, rest your legs, and prepare for the final leg of the journey to Machu Picchu tomorrow.

Machu Picchu: Today begins with an incredibly early start, but trust us – the reward will be worth every step! We’ll rise before dawn to begin our final ascent toward Machu Picchu, one of the most awe-inspiring and iconic sites on the planet. As the sun rises, you'll be treated to breathtaking views of the Incan citadel perched high above the surrounding mountains, shrouded in mist and glowing in the early morning light. Not familiar with Machu Picchu? This Incan citadel, constructed in the 15th century, is nestled atop a mountain peak in the Andes. Originally built as a royal estate and ceremonial centre, it was abandoned during the Spanish conquest and remained hidden from the world for centuries. It wasn’t until the early 20th century that Hiram Bingham rediscovered this magnificent place, and its lost history was slowly revealed to the world. After spending time marvelling at the wonder that is Machu Picchu, we’ll begin our descent and start the journey back to Cusco, where you’ll arrive in the evening. Take this opportunity to unwind and relax. Consider treating yourself to a well-deserved massage to soothe your muscles after the epic trek. Your evening is free, so why not explore the charming streets of Cusco or simply relax at your leisure? You've certainly earned it!

Cusco: After your grand expedition through the Andes, today is all about unwinding and taking a well-deserved rest! Enjoy a relaxed morning in Cusco, a city brimming with beauty and history. Start your day with a leisurely walk through the charming streets, and stop by a local café for a traditional Peruvian breakfast – perhaps a warm coca tea or a hearty plate of tamales. If you're in the mood to explore, wander through Plaza de Armas or browse the bustling San Pedro Market, where you'll find fresh produce, artisan goods, and plenty of local flavor. In the afternoon, we'll meet up and head to Sacsayhuamán, an awe-inspiring ancient Incan fortress that overlooks Cusco. The site is known for its impressive, colossal stone walls, which were meticulously constructed without mortar, showcasing the incredible skill of Incan engineers. As you walk through the site, you’ll be treated to breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding valley and Cusco itself. In the evening, it's time to dive into Cusco's legendary nightlife. Why not join the Cusco Bar Crawl and experience the city’s vibrant, energetic bar scene? You'll get to meet fellow travellers, enjoy great drinks, and make memories that will last long after your adventure ends. Cheers to an unforgettable journey!

Cusco to Puno: Today, we're setting off on an unforgettable journey to Puno – the next destination on our South American adventure. But this isn't just any ordinary travel day – we're following the Ruta del Sol (Route of the Sun), one of the most scenic routes in Peru, connecting Cusco to Puno. As we travel, you'll be treated to breathtaking views of the Andes, passing through rolling hills, vibrant valleys, and ancient ruins that tell the story of Peru’s rich history. Our first stop along the way is the world-famous Rainbow Mountain. This natural wonder, formed through tectonic activity, features vibrant, multi-colored earth that’s sure to take your breath away. We'll enjoy a short hike (around 1.5 hours) up to the peak, where you can snap plenty of photos and admire the surreal beauty of this striking landscape. So, don’t forget to charge your camera – you’ll definitely want to capture this! After soaking in the views, we’ll make our way back down and continue our journey to Puno. We'll arrive in the early evening, giving you some free time to settle in and get acquainted with this charming town, located on the shores of Lake Titicaca – the highest navigable lake in the world! Whether you want to take a leisurely walk around the town or just relax, it’s the perfect way to wind down after a day of incredible sights and adventure.

Puno: Today is filled with another unmissable experience as we embark on a boat ride across Lake Titicaca, one of the most stunning and culturally rich bodies of water in the world. Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site, Lake Titicaca is the largest freshwater lake in South America and also holds the title of the highest navigable lake in the world. The scenic beauty of the surrounding Andean mountains makes this a truly spectacular experience. During our boat ride, we’ll visit the famous floating homes of the Uros people. These homes are built entirely out of reeds from the lake and have been crafted by the Uros for centuries. They were originally created as a means of protection against the Inca Empire attacks. Today, the Uros people continue to live in these floating islands, preserving their unique culture and traditions. After an awe-inspiring day exploring Lake Titicaca, you’ll return to Puno for the evening. The night is yours to explore this vibrant town! Here are some options: - Hit up the bars and restaurants on Lima Street for a lively night out. - Watch a traditional Peruvian dance show, where you’ll get to experience the music, costumes, and dances that reflect the rich culture of the Andean region. - Or, for something a bit more relaxed, take a stroll through Plaza de Armas, where you can soak in the local atmosphere, catch street performances, and enjoy the beauty of the square at night. Whether you’re looking to unwind or party, this evening is your chance to soak up the energy of Puno before we head to our next adventure tomorrow!

Puno to La Paz: It’s an early start this morning as we board a sleeper bus at 5am from Puno to our next country – Bolivia. The journey takes roughly six hours, arriving in La Paz around lunchtime where your Adventure Leader will meet you before checking into your hostel. In the afternoon, we’ll explore the highlights of La Paz, Bolivia’s capital city. We’ll start at the central square, where you can see the Presidential Palace, the Cathedral of La Paz, and the National Congress building, before visiting the witch’s market – a lively and mystical spot offering traditional remedies, spiritual artefacts, and offerings for Andean rituals. In the evening, we’ll wrap up the day with a cable car ride, giving you stunning views of the city and the snow-capped Andes in the background.

La Paz: Are you an adrenaline junkie? Today, you have the option to mountain bike along the infamous World’s Most Dangerous Road. This thrilling ride takes you through lush valleys and breathtaking landscapes, but with vertical drops of up to 1,000 meters, it’s earned the nickname ‘Death Road.’ We partner with a trusted local company that prioritizes safety, ensuring you can enjoy this once-in-a-lifetime experience in a controlled and secure way. For those who prefer a more relaxed day, you’ll have free time to explore La Paz at your own pace, discovering more of the city’s hidden gems. In the evening, we’ll regroup and head to the bus station to board a lie-flat night bus from La Paz to Uyuni, arriving early in the morning.

Salt Flats Tour: Today kicks off an unforgettable three-day overland adventure in 4x4s, crossing Bolivia’s breathtaking salt flats and otherworldly landscapes all the way to San Pedro de Atacama in Chile. This is a true bucket-list experience you won’t want to miss! We’ll start in Uyuni with a visit to the eerie Train Cemetery, where rusting locomotives from Bolivia’s mining era lie abandoned in the desert. Then, we’ll head to the world-famous Salar de Uyuni, the largest salt flat on Earth. Depending on the season, you’ll either witness its surreal mirror-like reflections or endless stretches of bright white salt under a clear sky. Next, we’ll make our way to Incahuasi Island, also known as Fish Island, where giant cacti rise from the salt flats, creating an almost alien-like landscape. Here, we’ll enjoy a picnic lunch with stunning panoramic views. After lunch, get creative with some fun, perspective-bending photos on the vast salt flats—your Adventure Leader will be on hand to guide you. As the day winds down, we’ll settle into a remote guesthouse in the desert, where you can relax and soak in the unique surroundings.

Salt Flats Tour: Just when you thought the views couldn’t get any better, today’s journey takes us deeper into Bolivia’s stunning landscapes, starting with the Chiguana Desert. This vast sandscape is surrounded by towering volcanoes, including the still-active Ollagüe Volcano. Along the way, we’ll visit three breathtaking lagoons—Laguna Cañapa, Laguna Hedionda, and Laguna Honda—each boasting vibrant mineral-rich waters and home to flocks of flamingos. Watching these elegant birds against the backdrop of the multicolored lagoons is a true bucket-list moment! In the afternoon, we’ll venture into the Siloli Desert to see the famous Stone Tree (Árbol de Piedra), a striking rock formation sculpted over centuries by wind erosion. Keeping up the theme of jaw-dropping landscapes, we’ll continue to Eduardo Avaroa National Park, where we’ll visit the mesmerizing Laguna Colorada. This deep red lake, rich in minerals, is a haven for even more flamingos, creating a surreal and unforgettable sight. After an incredible day of exploring, we’ll settle in for the evening, enjoying dinner and some well-earned rest with the group.

Salt Flats Tour: Today starts bright and early, but trust us—it’s more than worth it! We’ll kick things off at the Sol de Mañana geyser field, where you’ll witness the otherworldly sight of steam rising from bubbling mud pools as the sun begins to rise over the high-altitude landscape. Next, we’ll head to the Polques Hot Springs for a well-earned soak in natural thermal waters, surrounded by the breathtaking desert scenery. Feeling refreshed, we’ll continue to the stunning Laguna Verde, a striking green lake set against the dramatic backdrop of the Licancabur Volcano. From here, it’s time to bid farewell to Bolivia and make our way to our fourth and final country—Chile! Crossing the border at Hito Cajón, we’ll descend into the Atacama Desert, the driest place on Earth. By the afternoon, we’ll arrive in the charming town of San Pedro de Atacama, where you’ll have the evening to relax, unwind, and soak in your new surroundings.

San Pedro de Atacama: Kick off the day with an adrenaline-pumping adventure as we head into Death Valley for an exhilarating morning of sandboarding down massive dunes! After carving through the sand, we’ll switch gears for a scenic bike tour to the breathtaking Lunar Valley (Valle de la Luna), a place so otherworldly it feels like stepping onto another planet. With its dramatic rock formations, rolling sand dunes, and shimmering salt flats, the valley offers jaw-dropping views of the vast Atacama Desert and the towering Andes beyond. It’s the perfect way to soak in this surreal landscape before wrapping up an unforgettable journey. For your final night, we’ll top it all off with a visit to an observatory. The Atacama Desert is one of the best stargazing spots on the planet, thanks to its high altitude, dry air, and minimal light pollution. Gaze up at the clearest night sky imaginable, spotting shooting stars, constellations, and the Milky Way in dazzling detail—an awe-inspiring way to end your adventure!

Santiago: Sadly, today marks the end of your incredible South American adventure. In the morning, we’ll transfer to the airport and catch a flight to Santiago, Chile’s vibrant capital. Upon arrival at the airport, it’s time to say your goodbyes as the tour officially comes to an end. Whether you’re continuing your travels or heading home, we hope you leave with amazing memories, new friendships, and plenty of stories to tell. Until next time, ¡buen viaje!

placesVisited: Quito, Galapagos Islands, Lima, Amazon Jungle, Cuzco, Sacred Valley, Inca Trail or Quarry Trail, Machu Picchu, Lake Titicaca homestay
generalInfo: Spend just over three weeks exploring the best of Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia via boat, bus, plane and train. Meet the unique wildlife of the Galapagos as you hike, cycle and bus around the islands, snorkeling with sea lions and meeting giant tortoises! Back on the mainland, get to know historic, beautiful Lima, before taking an internal flight to the depths of the Amazon jungle. Staying in a lodge for two nights, you’ll trek the forest with guides to spot giant otters, caiman and rainbow-coloured macaws. Another flight whisks you to Cuzco, the true heart of Peru, and from there get set to hike the tough but rewarding Inca Trail to ancient and extraordinary Machu Picchu, an abandoned Inca citadel in the clouds. Friendly locals and cities full of colour, energy and passion come as standard, and a night in a family homestay by Lake Titicaca will help you understand Peruvian life at first hand.

dayInfo.title: Quito.
dayInfo.description: Bienvenidos! Welcome to Ecuador. Sitting at an altitude of 2,850 metres, with stunning views of Volcan Pichincha, Quito is one of the most attractive cities in South America. You may even wish to arrive a day or two early and explore further beyond the city, visiting Otavalo, Cotopaxi or the Cloud Forest. Your adventure begins in Quito with a welcome meeting at 2 pm. Afterward, you'll join your local leader on a tour of the historic centre. Catch the metro to the Parque de la Alameda and visit sites such as the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus – a famous neo-Gothic church known for its facade representing Galapagos tortoises, Andean condors and Amazon alligators. You'll also visit La Compania de Jesus, considered by many to be the most beautiful church in the Americas. The tour will finish at San Francisco Square, then you'll have free time to relax or head out for dinner in Quito's Old Town – your leader will have plenty of recommendations!

dayInfo.title: Isla San Cristobal, Galapagos.
dayInfo.description: Catch an early morning transfer to Quito airport for your flight to San Cristobal Island in the Galapagos. The flight includes a stop in Guayaquil to pick up additional passengers (you will not need to disembark the plane). After joining up with your fellow travellers and your local naturalist guide on San Cristobal, head to La Loberia where you'll put on snorkelling gear for the first time and go for a swim among sea lions and maybe even some sea turtles! Return to town for a free evening tonight and maybe head out with the group for some fresh seafood.

dayInfo.title: Isla San Cristobal.
dayInfo.description: Take a 45-minute boat ride to Leon Dormido (Kicker Rock) this morning. On the way, you might be able to spot nesting frigates and blue-footed boobies. You might even get the chance to swim among the sea lions again. At Leon Dormido, you can snorkel and look for sea turtles, manta rays and the harmless Galapagos shark. Eat lunch on the boat, then head to the Interpretation Center. Learn about the history of the 'Enchanted Islands' and the conservation projects that seek to preserve them. Continue on your walk to Frigatebird Hill (Cerro Tijeretas) – for stunning views of the bay. Then, return to town in the late afternoon for a free evening.

dayInfo.title: Isla Floreana / Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: Take an early morning boat ride to Isla Floreana and look for dolphins and whales along the way. Snorkel in the clear blue waters and then break for lunch. After, venture to a black-sand beach belonging to the Witmers – descendants of some of the first settlers on the Galapagos. The town here – Puerto Velasco Ibarra – has about 150 residents and an intriguing history involving deaths, disappearances and murders. Head to a local restaurant for a traditional lunch. Continue to Isla Isabela later in the day, where you’ll settle in for the night.Later in the afternoon, wave goodbye to Floreana and continue to Isla Isabela, where you’ll spend the night.

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll hop on a small Zodiac boat and cruise to Las Tintoreras (Shark Alley), looking out for blue-footed boobies and the famous Galapagos penguin. Take a short walk on this isolated islet and popular iguana nesting site, then snorkel in a calm inlet with colourful fish and winding underground lava tubes. This area is also frequented by green sea turtles that like to rest on the calm, sandy bottom. Return to Isla Isabela and visit the Arnaldo Tupiza Tortoise Breeding Center, where you'll observe giant tortoises in all stages of development. After learning about the thousand turtles that are preparing for life here, you’ll head to a brackish lagoon to observe flamingos. Later today, take a kayak around the island and spend your evening resting in the sand and soaking in your first Isabela sunset – arguably the most beautiful of all the islands!

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela.
dayInfo.description: Start your last day on Isla Isabela by heading towards the Sierra Negra Volcano – one of the Galapagos’ most active volcanoes and the world's second-largest crater! Weather permitting, you’ll take a challenging hike of around 17 km up the rocky mountain. After, make your way back to town for some free time to curl up with a book, soak your tired muscles or venture down to the water for a relaxing swim before dinner.

dayInfo.title: Isla Isabela / Isla Santa Cruz.
dayInfo.description: Jump aboard a private speedboat this morning and head to Isla Santa Cruz. When you arrive, leave your bags at the hotel and head to the Santa Cruz Highlands. Your first stop is a local farm, where giant tortoises roam the grounds freely. Here, you’ll meet with an expert chef for a cooking class to make the famed encebollado – a local tuna soup that’s widely considered one of the best in the world! This hearty dish uses slow-cooked albacore tuna and a savoury broth made of onions, cilantro and spices. The dish is traditionally served with yuca (a starchy root vegetable) and garnished with lime and green onions. Enjoy the soups of your labour for lunch, then wander the grounds with the slow-paced residents. After lunch, you’ll visit an organic sugar cane farm run by a local family for a tour of their trapiche (a sugar cane mill used in artisanal sugar production). See how the family harvests and processes sugar cane and cacao and how they work with the local community.

dayInfo.title: Isla Santa Cruz.
dayInfo.description: Take a morning walk in Tortuga Bay after breakfast. Along the way, keep an eye out for eagle rays, sea turtles and blue-footed boobies. Later, you’ll head to the local fish market for a dose of local life on the way to The Galapagos Conservancy, who help protect the Galapagos' unique biodiversity. Learn how our Foundation supports the Galapagos Conservancy Women in Sustainable Entrepreneurship (WISE) program, which provides critical capital for sustainability initiatives and builds the entrepreneurial capacity of Galapagos women. After, head to the Charles Darwin Research Station – an international non-profit organisation that’s dedicated to the scientific research and conservation of the archipelago’s environment and biodiversity.

dayInfo.title: Quito.
dayInfo.description: Say goodbye to these enchanting islands and your Galapagos leader before taking a flight back to Quito, making a stop in Guayaquil on the way. You'll arrive in Quito later in the afternoon, where a representative will take you from the airport to your hotel. Enjoy a free evening in Quito.

dayInfo.title: Lima.
dayInfo.description: Say hasta luego to Quito and take an included flight to Lima, one of the most beautiful cities in South America. With Indigenous cultures dating back millennia, this country is a fascinating land of Amazonian rainforests, diverse wildlife and soaring mountains. You will be picked up from the airport and transferred straight to your hotel. In the evening you’ll meet your new leader and group members - perhaps get acquainted over some Pisco cocktails.

dayInfo.title: Amazon Jungle.
dayInfo.description: Rise and shine early today for your journey into the wilds of the Peruvian Amazon. Take an early transfer to Lima airport, then fly to Puerto Maldonado. Here, you’ll pack a small duffle bag with essentials for the next two days. Board a motorised canoe and cruise deep into the jungle. The journey to your eco-lodge in the Madre de Dios region will take a couple of hours, so you’ll stop for lunch along the way. Settle into your thatched-roof lodge before a short orientation walk of your surroundings. Spend the evening taking in the sights and smells of the jungle and enjoy an I’m-so-far-from-home moment.

dayInfo.title: Amazon Jungle.
dayInfo.description: Get ready for an unforgettable day exploring the depths of the jungle! Set out on a half-day trek guided by local experts on the area's flora and fauna. Learn from your guides about the medicinal and practical uses for some of the plants that grow here, which Indigenous people have been studying and using for thousands of years. On your walk, keep an eye out for rainbow macaws and butterflies, and listen for the barking call of the peccaries and chattering of monkeys that call the jungle home. This part of the Amazon is also known to house capybaras, giant otters and jabirus, so keep your eyes peeled for these exotic creatures.?Return to the lodge for lunch and some free time to relax. Once the sun goes down, venture out on a night walk in search of some of the jungle's nocturnal inhabitants (caimans, jaguars and anacondas).

dayInfo.title: Cusco.
dayInfo.description: Leave behind the natural wonders of the Amazon for the man-made wonders of Cusco. Return to Puerto Maldonado to collect your luggage, then take a short flight. If Lima is Peru's head, then Cusco is definitely the heart. Once you've spent some time acclimatising to the altitude of 3450 m, head out on an orientation walk with your leader. See the ancient and contemporary architecture styles, including the Plaza de Armas (Main Square), the San Pedro Market, the 12 Angled Stone, Regocijo Square and San Blas Square. This tour will also pass by the most significant temple in the ancient Inca empire?–?Qoricancha. Despite being covered with a Baroque facade in the 17th century by the Spanish, the original Inca masonry has been uncovered in some areas. In the evening, visit Casa for your trek briefing, then you’re free to explore at your own pace or find the perfect dinner spot with your group and try some local Peruvian favourites.

dayInfo.title: Ollantaytambo.
dayInfo.description: Hop on a private bus this morning and travel through the lush terraces of the Sacred Valley to Ollantaytambo – one of the few places where the Inca defeated the Spanish. On the way, stop at a village to enjoy lunch and conversation in a community that still practices many Inca traditions. Visit the AMA Restaurant in Urubamba – this cafe provides employment opportunities and job training for single mothers throughout the Sacred Valley. Enjoy a snack and learn how this inclusive enterprise focuses on economic growth, gender equality and the support of vulnerable communities. Continue your journey to Ollantaytambo, tonight, maybe you’d like to sit down for a dinner of quinoa and alpaca stew at one of the local restaurants.

dayInfo.title: Inca Trail.
dayInfo.description: Depending on the travel arrangements you made before the trip, during the next four days you’ll be either hiking the Inca Trail (Route 1), hiking the Quarry Trail (Route 2) or staying in Cusco for two days before taking the train to Aguas Calientes (Route 3). All routes visit Machu Picchu.? While away from Cusco, the bulk of your luggage will be stored at your hotel. If you’re hiking the Inca Trail or the Quarry Trail, the evening before you leave, you'll receive a small duffle bag to carry your clothes in for the next four days (5 kg maximum). Your team of porters will carry these bags for you, together with the food and equipment for the trail. You won't have access to these items until the end of each day, as the porters will always be ahead of the group. If you’re travelling to Aguas Calientes by train, you'll be able to leave most of your luggage at the hotel in Cusco and travel with only a small bag for the overnight stay in Aguas Calientes.? Route 1 Inca Trail? Today, travel by minivan to the 82 km marker and meet your crew of local porters, your cook and your guide. Your first day will include uphill trekking to the campsite, which sits at 3100 m above sea level. On the way, you’ll see the Inca sites of Ollantaytambo, Huillca Raccay and Llactapata, as well as incredible views of snow-capped Veronica Peak. In the evening, unwind at the campsite with a nourishing meal prepared by your cook.? Route 2 Quarry Trail? Make an early start today and drive to Choquequilla, a small ceremonial place where Incas worshipped the moon. From here, you’ll head to the small community near Qory Song’o (Golden Heart) hill, where you’ll climb to the top for the incredible views of the Soqma Perolniyoc, Pachar and Huarocondo valleys. There are also several sacred tombs in the area, protected by the locals, which you can explore with your leader and even see some of the original structure crafted from wood and leather. These remains have never been seen by travellers before, so you can be a part of this exclusive experience. Carry on to the Perolniyoc Cascade lookout, where you can stop for some snacks and photos. Arrive at the campsite, 3700 m above sea level, around lunchtime. After, set off to explore the Q'orimarca archaeological site, which once served as a checkpoint to the Incas.? Route 3 Cusco:? After spending the night in Ollantaytambo, take a short drive to the town of Pisac. Pisac is well known for its market. Here you’ll have the opportunity to shop for souvenirs and perhaps try some local empanadas. Arrive back at Cusco in the afternoon, where your leader can take you to San Pedro Market, where you have the option to buy some local favourites for a picnic tomorrow or enjoy having some free time. Perhaps head out for dinner– your leader will have plenty of local recommendations.

dayInfo.title: Inca Trail.
dayInfo.description: Route 1 Inca Trail This is the most challenging day of the trek, as you ascend a 5-hour long steep path to reach the highest point of the trail. Colloquially known as 'Dead Woman's Pass', Warmiwanusca sits at a height of 4200 m above sea level, providing amazing views of the valley below. The group will then descend to the campsite in the Pacaymayo Valley at 3650 m. Route 2 Quarry Trail This is the most challenging and rewarding day of the hike. A 3-hour walk takes you to the top of the first pass of Puccaqasa, about 4370 m high. After enjoying the picturesque views of the valley, it’s a short walk before stopping for lunch. After, make the 2-hour hike to Kuychicassa, the highest pass of the trek at 4450 m. From here, descend to the sacred site that the Incas called Intipunku. This is a sun gate, where the sun will stream through at particular times of the year and there are views of the Nevado Veronica mountain year-round. The Incas built several sun gates, the most notable overlooking Machu Picchu. Head to the campsite, only a stone’s throw away and at 3600 m.? Route 3 Cusco Today, take a taxi to Tambomachay, an archaeological site just outside of Cusco. From here you’ll take a 3 to 4 hours walk back to Cusco. On the way, stop to admire some of the archaeological sites, including Puka Pukara, Quenqo and Saksaywaman. Arrive back in Cusco in the early afternoon and enjoy some free time. Maybe visit the Merida, Mendivil and Olave art galleries and workshops before finding a great spot to sit down and enjoy some dinner.

dayInfo.title: Inca Trail.
dayInfo.description: Route 1 Inca Trail Start the day with a climb through the Pacaymayo Valley to Runkuracay Pass at 3980 m. Enjoy views of the snow-capped mountain of Cordillera Vilcabamba before descending for around 2 to 3 hours to the ruins of Sayacmarca. Continue over the trail’s third pass to the ruins of Phuyupatamarca at 3850 m, also known as the 'Town Above the Clouds'. Start the 2-hour descent down the Inca steps to the final night's campsite by the Winay Wayna archaeological site.? Route 2 Quarry Trail Today’s hike will all be downhill. The first stop is the incomplete Kachiqata quarry, where the Incas were intercepted by the Spanish. Explore the cobbled streets of Ollantaytambo when you finish your trek. This is where you’ll meet with the travellers in your group who didn't hike, before taking the short train journey to Aguas Calientes.Spend the night in a hotel before tomorrow’s visit to Machu Picchu. Route 3 Train to Aguas Calientes After a 1.5-hour drive to Ollantaytambo. This is where you’ll meet up with the travellers in your group who hiked the Quarry Trail. You’ll catch a 1.5-hour train through the winding Urubamba Valley to Aguas Calientes. The city is nestled in the cloud forest at the foot of Machu Picchu. Spend the night in a hotel before tomorrow’s visit to Machu Picchu.

dayInfo.title: Inca Trail.
dayInfo.description: Route 1 Inca Trail This is the final and most spectacular leg of the trek to Machu Picchu – one of the famed Wonders of the World. The day starts before dawn, with breakfast at 4 am. Say farewell to the porters as they descend to the train station and begin hiking. Once the final checkpoint opens at 5 am, you’ll begin the final 2.5-hour trek to Intipunku (the Sun Gate). Weather permitting, you’ll enjoy unforgettable views over the ‘Lost City of the Incas’ as you enter Machu Picchu through the Sun Gate.? ? Route 2 and 3 Machu Picchu to Cusco? Take an early bus up to Machu Picchu at 6:00 am. The city was built around 1440 AD as a country retreat for the Incan nobility, but there’s evidence that the land had been a sacred Incan site for much longer. Take a guided tour around the ruins of temples, palaces and living quarters. This is a day to remember!?? ? For all travellers, after taking advantage of the seemingly endless photo opportunities, it's time to catch the bus to Aguas Calientes, where you’ll stop for lunch together. From here, take a scenic train ride to Ollantaytambo, then drive back to Cusco, arriving in the evening.?

dayInfo.title: Cusco.
dayInfo.description: Enjoy free time to relax, shop and explore more of Cusco's many sights. Maybe rest your weary legs at a cafe on Plaza de Armas or head to the San Pedro Market where you can find vegetables, meats, local cheeses, chocolates, herbal medicines and many local handicrafts. It’s a great place to pick up souvenirs or ingredients for a picnic. The market is also where many locals (and daring travellers) go to eat ‘mystery soups.’ Some may be just chicken – however, the most popular among the locals usually contain frogs or offal. For those looking for something active, why not try mountain biking in the hills that surround Cusco?

dayInfo.title: Puno.
dayInfo.description: This morning after breakfast, travel through the dramatic scenery of the high altiplano to Puno – located on the shores of serene Lake Titicaca. At an altitude of 3800 m, Lake Titicaca is the world's highest navigable lake. Today includes a bit of a long drive in a local bus, but it’s worth the first glimpse of immense Lake Titicaca, whose?seemingly endless waters stretch into the horizon. Puno is a melting pot of Indigenous Aymara and Quechuan culture and traditional Andean customs, and it wears its traditions on its sleeve. If you're lucky, your trip will coincide with one of the many cultural festivals here. Ask your leader where you can get the best grilled trout tonight – a true local specialty perfect for dinner.? ?

dayInfo.title: Llachon community.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you’ll take a tour of the immense lake by motorboat, stopping at the floating Uros Islands that look like they could come from a Pixar or Studio Ghibli movie. Built by the Uros people to protect themselves from encroaching Inca forces hundreds of years ago, the islands are constructed from many layers of totora reeds that grow in the shallows of the lake. Get a closer look at contemporary life on the shores of the lake with a homestay in a local community.?Help your host family with their daily activities, try out a few words in the Quechua language and maybe even join a local soccer game to make some friends on the makeshift pitch. Tonight, sit down and swap stories with your hosts, who will cook you a feast full of traditional Peruvian favourites.

dayInfo.title: Puno.
dayInfo.description: This morning after breakfast, board another motorboat and cruise to Taquile Island – known for the intricate, hand-knitted textiles the locals produce.?Here, knitting is strictly a male domain and women do the spinning. It's a great place to pick up some high-quality, locally knitted goods, with the added bonus of supporting the local community. Then, take an hour uphill trek to the main area of the island, where you can shop for handicrafts. After, descend about 500 steps to the boat. Return to Puno, where you might like to gather your group and find a local watering hole to enjoy a drink or two – try a chilcano or indulge in another pisco sour.

dayInfo.title: La Paz.
