generalInfo:
DISCOVER the rich history, vibrant culture, and stunning landscapes of Peru and Bolivia as you journey to the heart of the Andes to the shores of South America’s highest lake.

VISIT the surreal terrain of the Uyuni Salt Flat, the largest in the world, and indulge in a gourmet picnic lunch at Incahuasi Island.

CRUISE the shimmering waters of Lake Titicaca, the highest navigable lake in the world, and visit the floating community of the Uros–Indigenous people.

WITNESS Andean Condors soar majestically over Colca Canyon, one of the deepest canyons in the world that plunges twice the depth of the Grand Canyon.

EXPLORE the UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Monastery of Santa Catalina—a centuries-old convent that spans over 20,000 square miles.

ENJOY an unforgettable Andean panpipes performance, widely regarded as one of the best folkloric performances in South America.

STAY in one-of-a-kind accommodations, including colonial-era hotels and a lodge almost entirely made of salt bricks.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Peru! Arrive at Alfredo Rodriguez Ballon International Airport (AQP) in the morning or early afternoon and enjoy a private transfer to your downtown hotel in Arequipa. Known as ‘the city of white volcanic rock’, Arequipa is built at the foothills of three volcanoes–Misti, Chachani, and Pichu Pichu. Our journey begins with a 5 p.m. Meet & Greet, where you'll get an overview of the days ahead—an unforgettable adventure through the highlands and heritage of Peru and Bolivia—and have a chance to connect with your fellow travelers, followed by dinner. Dinner included.

Following breakfast at the hotel, we’ll begin our first day of adventure with a walking tour of Arequipa’s UNESCO-listed historic center. Explore the Plaza de Armas, admire the Cathedral of Arequipa’s volcanic stone structure, and visit the Jesuit Church of La Compañía. Then, take in the splendor of this city at Yanahuara, a historic district known for its breathtaking views, where we’ll have lunch. Stroll through the local market and artisan streets in the afternoon. Return to the hotel afterwards for some rest before dinner at a local restaurant. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

After breakfast, explore San Camilo Market, Arequipa’s oldest and most traditional public market. Experience local culture and learn about the unique ingredients used in Peruvian cuisine. Next, we’ll visit the Monastery of Santa Catalina, a sprawling, centuries-old convent. Spanning over 20,000 square meters, this vibrant complex feels like a city within a city. After lunch at a local picantería, we’ll visit Museo Santuarios Andinos to learn about Mummy Juanita, a well-preserved Inca girl discovered atop Mount Ampato. This mummy offers insight into Incan culture, spiritual practices, and beliefs. Enjoy some free time relaxing in a café or shopping for local crafts before we return to the hotel for dinner and rest. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

After breakfast, we’ll depart and begin our journey to Colca Canyon—one of the five deepest canyons in the world. We’ll begin this drive through the Salinas and Aguada Blanca National Reserve, home to wildlife like guanaco, puma, and vicuña. Along the way, we’ll travel over the Patapampa Pass, reaching an altitude of 16,109 ft. (4,910 meters) above sea level. From this altitude, enjoy sweeping views of the rugged terrain and Mount Mismi—the source of the Amazon River. We’ll stop for lunch at a local restaurant in a small Andean village, indulging in tasty traditional dishes and warm drinks to help with acclimating to the altitude. During our drive through the highlands, we’ll encounter diverse wildlife like vicuñas, llamas, alpacas, Andean foxes, and flamingos. Learn more about how these animals adapt and thrive in extreme elevations. We’ll be on the lookout for these fascinating species as the wonders of the Andes unfold before us. We descend into the Colca Valley, passing through traditional Andean villages. After arriving at the hotel, you can rest or take a relaxing soak in its natural hot springs before dinner. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

Following an early breakfast at the hotel, we’ll depart for Cruz del Condor, the most famous viewpoint in Colca Canyon. Witness the breathtaking sight of Andean Condors soaring majestically over the deep canyon. These massive birds have wingspans reaching up to ten feet and glide on thermal currents during their daily search for food. Observe their routine and learn more about their significance in Andean culture and mythology. We’ll continue our drive across the Andean highlands towards Puno. The dramatic cliffs and winding roads make it feel as though the earth has split open to reveal this vast landscape. Admire the surrounding snow-capped peaks, vast plains, and herds of wild animals like vicuñas, alpacas, and llamas that roam freely. We’ll stop for lunch at a local restaurant, sampling traditional dishes. Our drive continues until we reach Puno, located on the shores of Lake Titicaca. This lake is the highest navigable lake in the world at 12,507 feet (3,810 meters) above sea level. Upon arrival, we’ll check into a waterfront hotel, offering a perfect place to relax and acclimatize. After settling in, join an optional lakeside walk. We’ll hopefully watch a beautiful sunset cast a golden hue over the waters of Lake Titicaca before gathering for dinner. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

After an early breakfast, we’ll head to the pier and board a motorized boat for an exciting day on Lake Titicaca. Explore the floating community of the Uros, an indigenous people who live on floating islands made by totora reeds. Learn more about their fascinating way of life as you explore their remarkable homes. Then, take a short ride in a traditional tortora reed canoe, a practice that dates back thousands of years. Next, we visit Taquile Island, which is often considered the most beautiful island on the lake. Stroll past terraced fields, rolling hills, and panoramic views of the glittering lake and surrounding mountains on a guided walk. This area is also known for UNESCO-recognized textile art, made by local artisans who create intricate woven garments that symbolize their cultural heritage. Meet the island’s Quechua-speaking locals, learn about their ancient customs that have been preserved for generations, and admire their remarkable textiles up close. We’ll sit down for a traditional lunch prepared by the islanders, featuring local trout, quinoa soup, and muña tea (a high-altitude medicinal herb). After spending time on the island, we’ll reboard our boat and head back to Puno for a relaxing lakeside evening. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

After breakfast we’ll begin the day with a scenic drive along the shores of Lake Titicaca. We’re driving to La Paz, Bolivia, today, and it’s one of the most breathtaking routes in the Andes! Take in the incredible sights of the vast lake, traditional Andean villages, and the majestic Cordillera Real mountain range. Following international border procedures, we head to Copacabana for lunch, a legendary beach town on Lake Titicaca. We cross the Tiquina Strait by boat and continue on to La Paz, Bolivia’s high-altitude capital. The transition from rural landscapes to the sprawling city nestled within a deep valley is quite dramatic. Once we arrive, enjoy an overhead look of La Paz from a modern cable car. The aerial ride provides an expansive view of the city’s vibrant neighborhoods, rugged mountain terrain, and bustling streets below. We check in at the Ritz Apart Hotel for a leisurely evening and enjoy a welcome dinner featuring Bolivian cuisine, such as salteñas, llama steak, or the famous sajta de pollo. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

Following breakfast, prepare for an exciting day in La Paz, the world’s highest altitude capital city—11,975 feet (3,650 meters)! We’ll begin our day with a cable car ride and visit to Plaza Murillo, the city’s historic square that’s home to the Presidential Palace, the National Congress building, and the La Paz Cathedral. After, we’ll drive to the Killi Killi Lookout Point, one of the best viewpoints in the city before exploring local markets and landmarks. We’ll learn more about local culture and spiritual traditions, admire Baroque-Mestizo architecture, and see an array of Bolivian handicrafts, textiles, and souvenirs. After lunch at a local restaurant, we’ll drive to Valle de la Luna (Moon Valley), a surreal landscape of eroded clay formations that resemble a lunar surface. Enjoy a short hike through the unique landscape and learn about the region’s geological history. The afternoon is yours to explore the city center, browse local shops, or take a leisurely stroll. In the evening, experience an unforgettable Andean-Pipes show at Restaurant Wari, widely regarded as one of the best folkloric performances in South America. The live music and dance showcase Bolivia’s rich cultural heritage and is paired with a delicious traditional Bolivian dinner featuring local flavors. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

After breakfast, we’ll transfer to the airport for our flight to Uyuni. Located in southwestern Bolivia, this town is known for its salt flats and vibrant history. The flight offers beautiful aerial views of the vast, arid landscapes of the Altiplano region. Upon arrival, we’ll visit the Train Cemetery, a collection of old steam locomotives and rail cars that date back to the early days of Bolivia’s railroad system. After lunch at a local restaurant, we’ll drive to the Pulacayo Mine. Pulacayo is one of the oldest and most important mining towns in Bolivia. The mine was once a key source of silver during the colonial era and played a significant role in Bolivia’s industrial revolution. Explore the remnants of the mine, including abandoned buildings, tunnels, and equipment. The area offers a glimpse into the harsh working conditions of miners from centuries past and the deep historical connection to Bolivia's mining culture. After a day of exploration, we will return to Uyuni and check in at Luna Salada Lodge. Relax and unwind after the day's adventure with a hearty dinner and an evening of rest. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

Following breakfast at the hotel, we’ll begin our journey to one of the most remarkable natural wonders on Earth—the Uyuni Salt Flat. We’ll drive across the vast, white expanse of salt, which stretches over 4,000 square miles (10,000 square kilometers) and is the largest salt flat in the world*. Our first stop is Colchani, a small village located at the edge of the salt flat. Here, we learn about the traditional methods used by locals to harvest salt from the flat. We also visit a salt treatment plant to see how raw salt is processed and prepared for sale. We’ll visit Incahuasi Island next (also known as Fish Island), a small hill of ancient volcanic rock rising from the middle of the salt flat. The island is famous for its giant cactus plants, some of which are over 700 years old. We’ll enjoy a picnic lunch on the island and take in the surreal views. During our journey back, we’ll find a perfect spot to enjoy the sunset over the salt flat. We return to Uyuni for our final night in town. We gather for our farewell dinner at the hotel. A delicious selection of Bolivian cuisine and international dishes will be served, and we will toast to the unforgettable experiences shared over the course of our journey. Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included.

Enjoy your final breakfast in Uyuni, reflecting on the incredible travel memories made. After breakfast, we’ll head to the airport for the flight back to La Paz, Bolivia. Take in stunning aerial views of the Andes mountain range and La Paz’s unique location in a vast valley surrounded by towering peaks. The guides will either drop you off at the El Alto International Airport (LPB) or at a downtown hotel depending on your plans. Breakfast included.

tourName: South America holiday, small group tour
placesVisited: Copacabana, Rio de Janeiro, Christ the Redeemer, Iguazu Falls, Buenos Aires, Sucre, La Paz, Tiwanaku, Lake Titicaca, Puno, luxury train to Cusco, Sacred Valley of the Incas, Machu Picchu, Lima
generalInfo:
This extended coast-to-coast spectacular takes in some of the continent’s most extraordinary and contrasting sites: exotic Rio de Janeiro, hemmed in by forested mountains and white-sand beaches; the thunderous falls at Iguazú; the sophistication of cosmopolitan Buenos Aires; the traditional, long-lasting indigenous culture of Bolivia; peerless Inca architecture in Cusco, Peru; the Lost City of Machu Picchu; and the shimmering waters of Lake Titicaca, fringed by snow-capped Andean peaks.
This comprehensive and comfortable trip introduces you to South America’s fascinating history and gives an insight into contemporary culture and ways of life.

dayInfo.title: Arrive in Rio, overnight overlooking Copacabana beach
dayInfo.description: Those passengers arriving on an international flight will be met by the tour leader or a local representative at the airport and escorted to the group hotel. Rio de Janeiro is the most romantic, intriguing and beautiful city on the continent. Sumptuous apartments overlook the sparkling bays against the backdrop of half-built slum dwellings, favelas, which cling precariously to the hillsides. Rio has an awesome bay-side location among near-vertical granite mountains. Here, tropical foliage swoops down to white-to-toffee coloured sandy beaches in turn battered by the huge waves of Atlantic surf. The drive into the city gives a fleeting glimpse of the docks and commercial centre as you head towards the magnificent stretch of sand at Copacabana beach where your hotel is located.

dayInfo.title: Explore Rio; cable car ride up Sugar Loaf Mountain.
dayInfo.description: You will explore Rio with a tour of the city to familiarise yourself with one of the most famous metropolises in the world. Highlights include the cathedral, Sambodromo and Maracana before a cable-car ride takes you up Pão de Açucar (Sugar Loaf Mountain), for expansive views of the city, its beaches, and the mountains beyond.

dayInfo.title: Visit Corcovado mountain and the famous Christ the Redeemer.
dayInfo.description: Today offers a trip to Corcovado mountain. This tour takes you on board a steep rack-and-pinion railway which glides up through tropical Tijuca National Park, the largest urban forest in the world dripping with fruit and flowers, to reach the summit of Corcovado. Here the famous 40m art deco Christ the Redeemer statue soars above the city, arms outspread benevolently. On a clear day the views over the city and out across the ocean and outlying islands are stupendous. Afterwards you may wish to do an optional excursion to the Botanical Gardens. Walk along the splendid Avenue of the Royal Palms, and see if you can catch a glimpse of the toucans and marmosets that frequent the park, attracted by thousands of species of tropical and subtropical plants. There are also glass houses sheltering bromeliads and a research institute here. You might take a drive through old Rio, the arty Santa Theresa district, where colonial houses in pastel hues line the winding, cobbled streets. Or simply head back to Copacabana beach, to watch the locals playing volleyball whilst enjoying a cold drink.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Iguazú Falls; explore the Brazilian side.
dayInfo.description: Fly to Foz do Iguaçú in the subtropical south-west corner of Brazil (2 hours). The Iguazú Falls are unquestionably one of the most extraordinary natural wonders in the world. A total of 275 falls thunder through dense forest over a 2.5km stretch. The U-shaped Devil’s Throat is the main gorge, where the frothy water of the Iguazú River crashes over a 1.5km-wide precipice and columns of vapour are thrown skyward. Elsewhere the river flows decorously through the rainforest breaking up into dozens of smaller falls. You might spot toucans with their outsized bright orange beaks perched in the foliage above the tumultuous waters. You head out to the Brazilian side of the falls, from where there is a broad panorama of these magnificent cataracts, and there are some excellent opportunities to photograph the full sweep of the cascades. Before leaving the Brazilian side, you could stop off at the excellent and rather quirky bird park just outside the entrance of Iguaçu National Park. The enclosure is home to a huge variety of birds and wildlife, including toucans, trogons and the coatimundi, from the same family as the racoon.

dayInfo.title: Iguazú Falls; explore the Argentine side.
dayInfo.description: You have a full day to explore the Argentine side of the falls. From the National Park Visitor Centre, where there is a display that illustrates the biodiversity of the region’s tropical rainforest, a little natural-gas-powered train transfers you to Cataratas Station where the Upper Walk begins. This sequence of causeways and passarelles links dozens of tiny basalt islands at the top of a sheer rock face and the walkways cross the myriad streams of the River Iguazú as they cascade over the lip of the precipice. Your breath is quite literally taken away as the water thunders on to the rocks below. The train continues to Devil’s Throat Station where a 1km-long walkway leads across the river to the thunderous Garganta del Diablo, the Devil’s Throat. From this vantage point you can feel the incredible power of the water, and the flow is mesmeric as it plummets into the vortex below.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Buenos Aires.
dayInfo.description: Transfer to the airport to fly south to Buenos Aires. The Argentine capital is an elegant, cultured and cosmopolitan city famed for its interesting museums and the fascinating port district of La Boca, with its cobbled streets and brightly painted houses. The afternoon is free to explore the area around your centrally located hotel or enjoy the cafés and restaurants for which Buenos Aires is famed.

dayInfo.title: City tour of the Argentinean capital.
dayInfo.description: The centre of town is home to the historic heartland, government buildings and churches as well as chic shopping districts, which have a nostalgic, Parisian feel. The bohemian district of San Telmo is full of quaint old houses interspersed with antiques shops, tango bars and extravagant restaurants. Close to the centre is the Gallic influenced Recoleta district where Evita Peron was laid to rest. We explore some of these quarters on our guided city tour, after which you can shop, have a drink and a pastry in an enticing coffee bar, peruse the items on display in one of the many markets or visit one of the city’s museums.

dayInfo.title: Fly to and explore the colonial city of Sucre.
dayInfo.description: A flight via Santa Cruz takes you to Sucre, the constitutional capital of the country (although La Paz is the seat of government); a sleepy whitewashed town with a leafy main square bordered by restaurants and the Supreme Court buildings. The climate is temperate and skies are clear, and wandering the cobbled lanes, stopping to investigate the many churches and museums is a lovely way to spend the day.

dayInfo.title: Fly to La Paz, the world's highest capital city.
dayInfo.description: Fly to La Paz. At over 3,500m, this is the highest capital city in the world. It is a glittering mosaic of tin, slate and tile roofs, interspersed with a line of skyscrapers that march down the valley. And beyond, keeping an eye on it all, is the colossal snow-capped Mount Illimani. This busy, commercial city has a 60% indigenous population; women dress in voluminous multi-coloured skirts, bowler hats and have centre-partings, as decreed by the Spanish monarch 3 centuries ago.

dayInfo.title: From La Paz, visit Tiwanaku pre-Columbian ruins.
dayInfo.description: You have plenty of opportunity to explore the colonial centre around Plaza Murillo and we will also take to the skies to ride the cable cars that offer a unique view of the city. There is also time for an included visit to the ruins of Tiwanaku. You travel out of La Paz and across the bleak, tawny earth of the altiplano, past glimmering lakes and herds of haughty alpacas. These pre-Columbian ruins are considered to be some of the most important on the continent, and the massive gateways and imposing walls are redolent of bygone glory.

dayInfo.title: By road to the shores of Lake Titicaca.
dayInfo.description: From La Paz take a scenic road trip to Lake Titicaca where you spend the night in a small hotel overlooking the sapphire water. The lake sits high in the Andes on the Peruvian- Bolivian border, and is focal point for subsistence farmers in the region who fish its icy waters and plant crops along its shores. The pretty little town of Copacabana where you stay is a religious sanctuary (and it gave Rio’s famous beach its name), and its whitewashed buildings and Moorish-style basilica are striking against a clear blue Andean sky. The Basilica is frequented by pilgrims to the miraculous 16th-century Dark Virgin of the Lake, and they bring their rickety cars to the forecourt, bedecked in flowers, to be blessed by her. If you have the energy in this rarefied air, climb the stations of the cross for views out over the lake and the snow-capped cordillera in the distance.

dayInfo.title: Lakeside drive to Puno, Peru.
dayInfo.description: In the morning there’s a chance to take an optional excursion to the Isla del Sol (Islands of the Sun). Here you will do a walk of about an hour with stunning views of the lake and island itself. Exploring the island gives you a chance to see how the local people live and work, almost unchanged over the years. Legend has it that this mystical spot marked the beginning of Inca civilisation. The children of the sun god sprung from the lake’s depths to found the mighty empire in Cusco, and a rock at the northern end of the island was their birthplace. After lunch back in Copacabana continue across the border to Peru, a journey that skirts the lake and has wonderful views arriving into Puno in the late afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Luxury train to Cusco.
dayInfo.description: A luxurious all-day train journey takes you from Puno to Cusco (10 hours) along one of the most scenic routes on the continent. First you cross the highland altiplano, a vast, windswept plain of bog and moor, where bowler-hatted indigenous women tend herds of llamas and alpacas, punctuated by the occasional market town. As the snow-dusted mountains close in, the train climbs to the high pass at La Raya (4,300m), and from here the scenery changes dramatically as you race down through the increasingly fertile pocket-sized fields of corn and potatoes to Cusco.

dayInfo.title: Tour of Cusco and Inca temple Sacsayhuamán.
dayInfo.description: An experienced guide gives you a detailed tour of Cusco, which includes a visit to several nearby Inca ruins. You visit Q’oricancha, once the principal Inca Sun Temple, with extraordinarily intricate stonework, and then explore the colossal zigzag walls of Sacsayhuamán, brooding on a hillside above Cusco. In 1536 a desperate and defining 3 day battle was fought between the Spaniards and the Incas around this fortress; the first conquistadors to see it were overawed and centuries later it is still an extraordinary and imposing sight.

dayInfo.title: Excursion to the Sacred Valley of the Incas, overnight.
dayInfo.description: A full-day adventure visits several of the villages and archaeological sites which pepper the Sacred Valley of the Incas. The Pisac complex, set high above the eponymous village, is composed of steep terraces; their engineering and preservation are unrivalled, and you can clamber among the ancient walls and explore the ruins of temples, residences and storehouses. It takes about an hour and a half to explore the site, after which you stop off in the village below where an arts and crafts market spills across the main square, stalls laden with tapestries and weavings crafted in the surrounding villages. Continue along this picturesque, patchwork valley to Ollantaytambo, the snow-capped Andean cordillera forms a stunning backdrop. The Inca fortress towering above the adobe village is well preserved and there are wonderful views down over the gentle sloping hillsides and into the fertile valley. You spend the night in the Sacred Valley.

dayInfo.title: By rail to Machu Picchu; guided tour of the site.
dayInfo.description: A dramatic 2 hour train journey from Ollantaytambo delivers you to the ruins of Machu Picchu. As the river Urubamba enters its narrow gorge between thickly-forested granite hills, there is room only for a single rail track, which hugs the right bank and passes through hamlets which are no more than a collection of shacks. The citadel is then reached by minibus up a sinuous road. In 1911 the American explorer Hiram Bingham discovered the ruins buried beneath tropical cloud forest. It is the city’s location which most captures the imagination, on a ridge spur amid forested peaks and above a roaring river canyon. Following a guided tour or the ruins you spend the night in the village of Machu Picchu. Fancy hiking some of the Inca Trail without interrupting your tour? We can organise for you to walk the mini Inca Trail on this day, but still, have a guided tour of the ruins and stay with the group in the evening. Please ask us for more details.

dayInfo.title: Optional revisit to Machu Picchu. Return to Cusco.
dayInfo.description: You have the optional opportunity to revisit the ruins, rail schedules permitting. There is also the chance for the more challenging hike to Huayna Picchu, the conical peak which juts out behind the ruins for wonderful views over the site. There’s also the option of the slightly easier climb of Machu Picchu Mountain. If you think you’d like to re-visit the site or do one of the climbs please enquire with the office, as spaces are limited and it’s necessary to pre-book. You may prefer to relax and wander the narrow vehicle-free streets of Machu Picchu village, lined with souvenir shops and cafés. You return to Cusco on the afternoon train, arriving in the late afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Fly to Lima.
dayInfo.description: Fly to Lima (1 hour). The City of Kings was once the capital of Spanish America, and the remnants of its glorious past can still be seen in the faded grandeur of the colonial churches and splendid, traditional wooden balconies in the city centre. The explosive growth of the last 50 years, so typical of capital cities in the developing world, has transformed Lima into a bustling and chaotic low-rise city of over 6 million people. Away from the busy centre, there are some superb traditional restaurants as well as archaeological museums filled to the rafters with pre-Columbian treasures. In crowded streets, throngs of traffic race out towards Miraflores, on the coast, a modern middle-class suburb where your hotel is located.

Travelling from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific, you’ll start out on laid-back, white-sand beaches and pass through dense forests before ascending into the Andes, where the bleakness of the Altiplano is breathtaking. The contrast between the tropical coast and the ice-capped Andean peaks is matched only by the contrast in cultures: cosmopolitan Rio, quaint colonial architecture, ancient Inca temples and modern Aymara markets spanning influences from Africa, Europe and the Andes.

This South America coast to coast tour starts in one of the world’s most dramatically situated cities: Rio de Janeiro, which faces onto Atlantic bays with a backdrop of steep, forested mountains. Ramshackle favelas cling to the hillsides; the beautiful people hang out on Copacabana Beach to see and be seen, and Christ the Redeemer surveys it all from on high. From Rio, you’ll fly up to Iguazu Falls, where 275 cataracts crash through the tropical vegetation of the surrounding wildlife-filled national park.

Crossing into the South American time warp that is Paraguay, you’ll visit the nostalgic and tranquil capital, Asuncion, before flying up to La Paz. At 3,500m above sea level (and the airport is even higher…) La Paz is literally breathtaking. Travel across the Andes to Lake Titicaca, which straddles the border between Bolivia and Peru – you’ll explore both sides of the lake, including the charming town of Copacabana, and the floating Uros Islands, made of totora reeds. Your South America coast to coast tour ends on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, in Lima.

This rather old world, eclectic city is located on the shores of the Río Paraguay, and an air of nostalgia permeates its busy streets. Paraguay feels caught in a time warp, the legacy of years of isolation from the outside world under the rule of a series of dictators. The wide, tree-lined avenues, parks and stately buildings are impressive, and you will explore them on your walking tour of the capital.

The u-shaped Devil’s Throat is the main gorge, where the frothy water of the Iguazú River crashes over a 1.5km-wide precipice and columns of vapour are thrown skyward. Elsewhere the river flows decorously through the rainforest breaking up into dozens of smaller falls. You might spot toucans with their outsized bright orange beaks perched in the foliage above the tumultuous waters. dayInfo.title: Visit the Brazilian side of the falls and fly onto Rio de Janeiro.
dayInfo.description: In the morning you’ll head out to the Brazilian side of the falls, from where there is a broad panorama of these magnificent cataracts, and there are some excellent opportunities to photograph the full sweep of the cascades. Continue onto Foz do Iguaçú airport and fly to Rio de Janeiro (2 hours). Rio de Janeiro is the most romantic, intriguing and beautiful city on the continent. Sumptuous apartments overlook sparkling bays against a backdrop of half-built slum dwellings, favelas, which cling precariously to the hillsides. Rio has an awesome bay-side location among near-vertical granite mountains. Here, tropical foliage swoops down to white-to-toffee coloured sandy beaches in turn battered by the huge waves of Atlantic surf. The drive into the city gives a fleeting glimpse of the docks and commercial centre as you head towards the magnificent stretch of sand at Copacabana beach; your hotel is close by.

dayInfo.title: Guided tour of the city including Sugarloaf Mountain.
dayInfo.description: Today there is a tour to familiarise yourself with this most iconic of cities. As part of this we also include a trip to Pão de Açucar (Sugar Loaf Mountain). Ride the cable-car up the twin granite mountains protruding from the ocean and enjoy the magnificent views back over the beaches, Botafogo Bay with its bobbing yachts and into the mountains beyond. Theres a lovely (and safe) nature walk round the foot of the mountain, or you could pop for a beer into the nearby villagey quarter of Urca, leafy home of artists and TV stars.

dayInfo.title: Further exploration of Rio including Corcovado Mountain.
dayInfo.description: In the morning you’ll board a steep rack-and-pinion railway which glides up through tropical Tijuca National Park, the largest urban forest in the world dripping with fruit and flowers, to reach the summit of Corcovado Mountain. Here the famous 40m art deco Christ the Redeemer statue soars above the city, arms outspread benevolently. On a clear day, the views over the city and out across the ocean and outlying islands are stupendous. The afternoon is at leisure. A popular optional excursion is a visit to the exotic Botanical Gardens. Walk along the splendid Avenue of the Royal Palms, and see if you can catch a glimpse of the toucans and marmosets that frequent the park, attracted by thousands of species of tropical and subtropical plants. There are also glass houses sheltering bromeliads, and a research institute here.

tourName: Toro Toro National Park tour, Bolivia
placesVisited: Toro Toro National Park, Dinosaur footprints, Colourful colonial towns, Umujalanta Cave system, Ancient rock paintings, Ciudad Itas natural 'city of stone', Vergel Canyon
generalInfo:
The stunning Toro Toro National Park remains an off-the-beaten track destination that is a perfect add-on to any trip to Bolivia for anyone looking for a less strenuous South American adventure experience. Its highlights include some of the best preserved dinosaur footprints in South America, stunning geological formations plus pleasing colonial towns.

Travelling from the atmospheric city of Cochabamba, private 4x4s cover the rugged road to Toro Toro. Pause en route at the colonial village of Tarata to admire its beautiful crumbling colonial facades. Then don torch helmets to explore the nearby Umajalanta Cave – a remarkable partly explored arena of giant stalagtites and stalagmites, blind fish and stunning rock formations.

Another day, climb to 4000m for stunning mountain views as you head for the unique Ciudad Itas – a natural 'city of stone' created by millennia of rock erosion. Here too are rock paintings estimated to be around 2000 years old. This is also your first encounter with the thousands of dinosaur footprints that are a highlight of the Park – including the mighty 36m long Titanosaurus.

You'll also explore the depths of the Vergel Canyon, overseen by soaring condors. At the bottom of the canyon, a wonderful natural pool formed by a waterfall provides a perfect swimming spot.

dayInfo.description: We recommend you arrive in Cochabamba today (although it is possible to start your trip straight from the airport the next day if you prefer). The arrival day in Cochabamba is not included in our services but we can arrange travel to Cochabamba (by air or bus) and hotels for you should you wish to add these on.

Today we travel to the village of Toro Toro. The journey takes approximately 4 hours and is by private 4x4. Roads are unpaved and bumpy, but it's worth it and scenic views make up it. We will stop at the colonial village of Tarata to admire the crumbling yet beautiful colonial facades. In the afternoon we head to the nearby Umajalanta Cave, enjoying the first views of the iconic hills of the national park. At the cave we don helmets and torches to enter the cave. The cave is estimated to be 7km deep, although it is unkown how much of it remains unexplored. Huge stalagtites and stalagmites can be seen, as well as blind fish and stunning rock formations. The visit can be as adventurous as you like it to be - full on caving, or a more leisurely visit of the first part of the cave. Overnight at Cabanas Umajalanta

Today we will drive into the mountains and slowly climb higher until we reach an altitude of 4000m. From up here the views are stunning and we will make plenty of photo stops on our way to "Ciudad Itas", a place that resembles a city (ciudad) of stone, including its very own "cathedral". The formations are fascinating, created over thousands of years as water eroded the stones. Small caves have developed and we can find rock paintings that are estimated to be some 2000 years old. The lucky ones may see a condor soar. The afternoon is all about the mighty dinosaurs. Thousands of footprints have been uncovered in the National Park and our guide will find the best preserved for us. Overnight at Cabanas Umajalanta.

We cannot leave Toro Toro without visiting one of its many canyons. The Vergel Canyon is one of the deepest canyons at around 250m. Before we begin our descent we stop to admire the views from a vantage point high over the canyon. Vultures can usually be seen soaring, so keep your eyes peeled for the mighty condor. At the bottom of the canyon we walk across boulders and along a small path to a wonderful natural pool, formed by the Vergel Waterfall. Time for a refreshing dip. We then return back to the 4x4 and on our way back to the village stop one last time to see some of the park's biggest dinosaur footprints, left by the mighty 36m long Titanosaurus. We return to Cochabamba where this trip ends. Your hotel in Cochabamba is not included but we can arrange this for you.
Onward travel or extension in Cochabamba. Services not included but can be added on for you, please ask.
